Headline: =WSJ: Cerberus Emerges As Lead Contender For Chrysler-Sources
Story: By Dennis Berman, Gina Chon and Jason Singer     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     Private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management was emerging over the weekend as the leading contender to assume control of venerable automaker Chrysler Group, according to people familiar with the matter.   As its German parent DaimlerChrysler AG (DCX) rushes to complete a sale of the struggling unit, it is still possible that a buyout group led by Canadian auto parts maker Magna International Inc. (MGA) could emerge as Chrysler's owner, these people said.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   There is typically a gamesmanship in such auction situations, as bidders vie for an angle, sometimes pulling back from the action before striking with a new offer or plan.   Cerberus, DaimlerChrysler and Magna declined to comment.   Whatever the outcome, Daimler was setting up some general guidelines for its deal. As described by three people familiar with the matter Friday, Daimler would contribute Chrysler into a new corporation while keeping a minority stake in the business.   Chrysler's $18 billion in pension and health-care liabilities - the key factor of the deal - would travel along with the rest of the company. The new company would be majority owned by the new buyer.   This party would then contribute a big slug of equity to fund the operations, these people said. The extent of any payment to Chrysler couldn't be learned Friday, but it was possible it could be small or in fact no payment could be made.   Daimler is rushing to cut an agreement prior to renewed negotiations that kick off this summer with the United Auto Workers union, whose approval is essential to the success of any transaction.   Any new owner would also have to satisfy the U.S. Pension Benefit Guarantee Corp., which monitors the health of corporate pension plans.   Daimler is moving briskly in hopes of moving Chrysler off its books as soon as possible. But it faces potentially big challenges from the UAW, which could effectively scuttle a deal by holding out for its own desires.   People with knowledge of the transaction describe the process as extremely fluid, and say details could change at the last moment. Negotiations are still ongoing and have yet to be concluded, people familiar with the matter said.   DaimlerChrysler has been negotiating with several partners after Chief Executive Dieter Zetsche announced on Feb. 14 that all options were on the table for Chrysler, including a possible sale.   In addition to Cerberus and Magna, a team made up of the Blackstone Group and Centerbridge Capital Partners submitted a second round of bids recently. But billionaire Kirk Kerkorian's Tracinda Corp. has been shut out of the talks so far.   Cerberus was seen as a strong contender because of its financial resources and its ability to create synergies with Chrysler Financial due to Cerberus' 51% stake in GMAC, the financing arm of General Motors Corp. (GM).   Magna was more favored by some labor representatives because it was seen as a long-term investor, as opposed to private equity, which was perceived as interested in Chrysler only to make a quick profit.   Cerberus strengthened its bid even further after it hired former Chrysler Chief Operating Officer Wolfgang Bernhard as an adviser. Bernhard is highly regarded by his former Chrysler colleagues and was seen as a hands-on manager.   But a Cerberus bid is likely to face opposition from the unions, which have said they oppose a private equity takeover of Chrysler. Cerberus led a group of investors in a deal to buy auto supplier Delphi Corp. (DPHIQ), and asked for wage and other cuts from the UAW. That produced a contentious relationship between the private equity firm and the UAW, and Cerberus will likely back out of the Delphi deal.     -By Dennis Berman, Gina Chon and Jason Singer, The Wall Street Journal; Dennis.Berman@wsj.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 15:26 ET (19:26 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining more than 5% of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from May 3 through May 9. Source: Dow Jones Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     National Home Health Care (NHHC)   Lawndale Capital Management said that a proxy-advisory firm has recommended that shareholders vote against National Home Health Care's proposed buyout offer from alternative-investment firm Angelo Gordon & Co. Lawndale Capital said that Institutional Shareholder Services, or ISS, has deemed the sales process "not properly managed."   ISS agrees with many of the concerns raised by Lawndale and doesn't understand whyan auction process couldn't have been conducted.   Lawndale Capital Management currently holds 395,389 shares (7% of the total shares outstanding).     3Com (COMS)   Citadel Investment Group would like to meet with the management and board to discuss the networking-systems company's strategy. Citadel Investment believes that many options exist today for the creation of substantial value for 3Com's shareholders, but it didn't specify what those options are in the letter.   Citadel Investment reported ownership of 33,492,877 shares (8.4%).     Alliance Bancorp (ALLB)   PL Capital Advisors intends to influence the company's policies and assert shareholder rights, with the goal of maximizing long-term value of Alliance stock. PL Capital may make further purchases of the Pennsylvania banking company's shares, although it now has no intention of increasing its holdings above 9.99%.   PL Capital currently owns 379,666 shares (5.3%).     Penn Traffic (PTFC)   Bay Harbour Management intends to continue to seek representation on Penn Traffic's board. Bay Harbour said that it's "concerned" that it has no representation on the board, and suggested that Penn Traffic increase the number of directors and elect one of its designees to fill the vacancy, which the company has refused to do.   Bay Harbour said it has been negotiating with the food distributor and supermarket owner to enter into a confidentiality agreement to assist the company in addressing its financing alternatives, but that the parties have been unable to reach an agreement. As of Feb. 16, Bay Harbour reported ownership of 1,912,992 shares (23.1%).     Glenayre Technologies (GEMS)   Third Point urged Glenayre Technologies' management to immediately begin an auction to sell the company, which makes prerecorded CDs and DVDs, among other items.   Third Point said that the "only logical decision" for Glenayre Technologies' management and board is to immediately hire financial advisers to arrange a sale. Third Point currently holds 4,415,000 shares (6.3%).     Comarco (CMRO)   Elkhorn Partners intends to nominate three directors for election to the board at the company's 2007 shareholders' meeting.   The nominees are William H. Evers Jr., chief executive officer of Systems Technology & Science; Alan S. Parsow, general partner of Elkhorn; and Sean T. Mullen, a principal of the public-accounting and consulting firm Hancock & Dana.   Elkhorn Partners currently owns a stake of 9.1% -- 668,898 shares -- of Comarco stock outstanding. The company makes mobile-power adapters that can be used in recharging products such as laptop computers and cell phones.     Original Filings     Cowlitz Bancorp (CWLZ)   Crescent Capital VI reported ownership of 483,000 shares (9.8%), after buying 348,858 from March 2 to April 30 at $16.73 to $17.16 a share.     Increases in Holdings     Unisys (UIS)   MMI Investments raised its holdings to 27.96 million shares (8.1%), from 24.35 million (7.1%), reported in March.     Decreases in Holdings     Tech/Ops Sevcon (TO)   Hummingbird Management cut its holdings to 211,925 shares (6.6%), after selling 86,250 from April 24 to May 4 at $9.20 to $10.89 each.     Build-A-Bear Workshop (BBW)   Investor Philip C. Timon, who manages Endowment Capital Group, lowered his stake to about 2.18 million shares (10.6%), from 2.64 million shares (12.9%), reported on Jan. 11.     Martin Marietta Materials (MLM)   Third Point reduced its holdings to about 1.99 million shares (4.5%), from a previous stake of three million shares (6.6%), reported on Feb. 12.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Follow-Up: A Stronger Signal For Clear Channel Sale
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   The $26 billion leveraged buyout of Clear Channel Communications, which looked doomed a week ago, has found new life, thanks to last-minute concessions by the private-equity firms seeking to win control of the country's largest radio operator.   By offering public shareholders a 30% stake in the surviving company, the private-equity firms, led by Bain Capital Partners and Thomas H. Lee Partners, may win over enough institutional holders to carry a shareholder vote on the deal.   There was speculation last week that the biggest opponent of the transaction, Fidelity Investments, which holds 10% of Clear Channel shares, is willing to go along with the new proposal, which was hashed out with some dissident holders. The Fidelity rumors helped lift Clear Channel shares (ticker: CCU), which finished Friday at $37.78, up 1.43 on the week. A Fidelity spokesman declined to comment. One sizable shareholder, Highfields Capital Management, is believed to favor the new proposal.   The new offer, which is being weighed by Clear Channel's board, would give public holders the choice of accepting $39.20 a share in cash or a combination of cash and publicly traded stock in the surviving company. The 30% equity interest will come in the form of $1.2 billion of new stock with the private-equity firms retaining 70%. The old offer, which faced rejection last week, was an all-cash deal at $39.   Wall Street arbitragers now are putting a reasonable likelihood on the deal's success. At Clear Channel's current price, the stock offers a 10% yield to the deal price, assuming the transaction closes in five months.   Much has to happen, however, for the new deal to fly. Clear Channel's board, which postponed a shareholder vote on the old proposal to May 22, still needs to agree to offer the new proposal to shareholders in a vote that would take place in July or August. Then the proposal needs to garner the support of two-thirds of shareholders, a high hurdle rate considering that shareholders who don't vote effectively are casting ballots against the deal.   The benefit of the new proposal is that it offers Clear Channel holders a choice of cash or a mix of cash and stock. The equity will be in a highly leveraged company, creating a high risk/high reward situation.   One group that stands to do well is the private-equity buyers. By agreeing to offer a 30% equity stake to buyers, Bain and Thomas Lee may have salvaged a deal that allows them to effectively buy Clear Channel's radio business at an estimated nine times projected 2007 pre-tax cash flow, below the valuation on most publicly traded radio stocks.   If the Clear Channel bulls are right, the private-equity buyers could double their money in a year or two. Current public shareholders would benefit if they elect the stock option, but the big winners -- not surprisingly -- will be the private-equity types who have made a killing in so many other LBOs.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK Fund Marathon Resists Temasek Offer For Stats Chippac
Story: SINGAPORE (Dow Jones)--U.K.-based fund manager Marathon Asset Management has confirmed it won't accept the takeover offer for Stats Chippac Ltd. (S24.SG), potentially preventing Temasek Holdings Pte Ltd. (TEMAH.YY) from taking the chip tester private.   Marathon, which says it owns about 6.5% of Stats, believes the company has strong growth prospects and is undervalued by Temasek's offer, said portfolio manager Jeremy Hosking in a telephone interview late Friday.   Hosking, who has crossed swords with Temasek before, said it's "academic" whether Temasek raises its offer or not as Marathon plans to hold onto its stake.   Temasek, an investment arm of the Singapore government, declined to comment.   Temasek made its takeover offer in March, valuing the Nasdaq- and Singapore-listed company at S$3.57 billion ($2.35 billion). The investment company offered to pay S$1.75 a share if it got minimum acceptances of 50%, which would rise to S$1.88 a share if acceptances crossed 90%.   As Temasek owned 35.6% of Stats before making its takeover offer, its stake needs to rise to about 93.5% for shareholders to get S$1.88 a share. It owned 79.9% of Stats on Friday, according to a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.   Singapore business publication The Edge said in its May 7 issue that Hosking almost single-handedly scuppered the privatization of another Temasek-related company, SembCorp Marine Ltd., in 2002 because he thought minorities were being offered far too little.     -By Stephen Wright & Vladimir Guevarra, Dow Jones Newswires; 65 6415 4151; stephen.wright@dowjones.com; vladimir.guevarra@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 04:19 ET (08:19 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) A Chance To Rewrite The Financial League Tables
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   The financial data of Thomson suffered a blot in March when some professors revealed integrity problems in the company's popular database of stock-analyst recommendations, known as I/B/E/S. A deal disclosed last week for Thomson to acquire Reuters Group Holdings should help remedy those data deficiencies -- and address a much larger problem known as Bloomberg.   The still-unfinished agreement to merge Thomson (ticker: TOC) and London's Reuters (RTRSY) would boost theresulting entity's financial-market sales well ahead of those of Bloomberg, the privately held firm whose huge success allowed  founder Michael Bloomberg to take time off to become mayor of New York.   A Thomson-Reuters company would get 60% of its revenues from financial customers and enjoy an almost comfortable duopoly with Bloomberg in the market for financial-data workstations.   That sort of limited competition is what Thomson, a Canadian icon now based in Stamford, Conn., already enjoys with its online legal data -- the source of half of current revenues -- as it competes against the Lexis-Nexis unit of Reed Elsevier (RUK) and the Dutch Wolters Kluwer.   If the $18 billion cash and stock deal comes off, therefore, Thomson-Reuters would have improved data products and greater pricing flexibility. Costs would also drop. The companies have targeted $500 million in post-merger savings, on top of aggressive restructuring campaigns that each  already had under way. Those restructuring programs helped the stocks of both Thomson and Reuters rise smartly in recent years, and near $42, Thomson shares trade at a somewhat higher multiple of earnings than other information vendors.   But assuming that humans continue to trade and litigate, shares of Thomson should do  well. If targeted savings materialize, the resulting cash flow could make them worth about 20% more than their recent levels.   Since its start almost 75 years ago in Canadian newspapers, Thomson has entered and exited many industries, including TV, travel and oil exploration. The company began ditching its newspapers in the 1990s, and Richard J. Harrington accelerated that strategy after becoming chief executive 10 years ago. In 2003, it left the newspaper business completely by selling its remaining interest in Toronto's Globe and Mail to a holding company controlled by the descendents of founder Roy H. Thomson (whose newspapering success around the Commonwealth got him the Scottish title of the Right Honorable Lord of Fleet). The family's Woodbridge Co. still firmly controls Thomson, with two-thirds of the voting shares.   As chief executive, Harrington raised capital by unloading nonstrategic businesses and listing the Canadian company on the New York Stock Exchange. He used that capital to buy up dozens of businesses that sell online data to diverse professions: lawyers, accountants, investors and scientists. Of Thomson's $6.6 billion in 2006 revenues, some 55% came from legal and regulatory data services like the Westlaw database of judicial decisions. About 30% of revenues came from financial data products like the I/B/E/S collection of analyst estimates. Scientific and health-care data brought in the remaining 15% of '06 sales, with stuff like ISI The Web of Science -- an always fascinating record of the most-cited scientific papers.   Even though Thomson revenues grew a modest 8% last year, earnings jumped 26% to about $860 million, or $1.34 a share. Free cash flow rose 21% to $1.4 billion (which represented operating cash flow minus capital spending). That profit growth followed an aggressive restructuring program in which Thomson chopped overhead by combining 80 financial-data products into the single ThomsonOne platform, for instance.   Investors have responded by bidding up the shares about 40% since the Toronto-traded company dual-listed on the Big Board in 2002. That's not quite as strong a rally as the S&P 500, but it's way better than other stocks with a newspaper legacy, like Barron's publisher Dow Jones (DJ).   Thomson's operating profit margin on its legal databases was 31% last year. The operating margin at Thomson Financial was slimmer, however, at 19%. The competition has been tougher in the financial-data business, where Bloomberg has motored into the lead with $4.7 billion in 2006 revenues and operating margins of about 30% (according to a recent story in Fortune magazine, which a Bloomberg spokesperson said was accurate). Reuters runs second in financial data, racking up total company sales of about $5 billion, including trading platforms and other businesses. Thomson Financial's $2 billion in 2006 revenue puts it third...followed distantly by a rabble of smaller financial-data vendors (including Dow Jones).     While Thomson has been making astute business moves, its financial data have accumulated some bad marks from Wall Street's sharp-eyed quantitative analysts. You don't have to be a quant to notice problems. We initially pulled the data for this article's comparative table from Thomson -- but some of the numbers looked wrong. Checking the underlying company reports, we saw that Thomson's data were wrong. We then fetched the relevant data from Bloomberg and Reuters; they had the figures right.   Our experience may not have been a fluke. A working paper by three finance professors has found that almost 55,000 alterations were made in Thomson's I/B/E/S database of analyst recommendations -- changes that had the curious effect of making the analysts look smarter than they actually had been (see "Mysterious Changes in Key Wall Street Data," in Barron's March 5 issue).   Thomson's initial response to the professors' findings was Nixonian. It refused to acknowledge any I/B/E/S problem and even threatened to sue the academics and their universities. But in March of this year, the professors presented even more evidence that the I/B/E/S data were a mess. Thomson has since asked the professors to help it attempt to fix the data. The merger could fix Thomson's damaged data and brand, since Thomson Financial would be subsumed under the Reuters name.   A combination would work much larger changes, of course. Together, the two companies' financial-product revenues exceeded $7 billion last year. If the merged companies were to wring the $500 million in annual savings contemplated in Tuesday's announcement, that would be worth four percentage points of profit on their combined 2006 sales level of $12 billion.   The terms of the deal aren't final, but the joint announcement last week said Thomson was offering 352.5 pence (about US$7) cash and 0.16 Thomson shares for each share of Reuters' stock. That valued Reuters at 697 pence per share -- a generous 15 times Reuters' per-share cash flow and 25 times the average estimate for its 2008 earnings. Helping to finance a deal would be Thomson's just-announced sale of its textbook and education businesses for $7.75 billion.   The London-listed shares of Reuters jumped at the news of Thomson's offer -- but only from about 500 to 613 pence, reflecting a 5% slide in Thomson shares since the preceding week, as well as investors' uncertainty about the deal.   Antitrust regulators in Britain and the U.S. would have to review the merger, of course. And a trust that's charged with protecting the integrity of the Reuters news service also has a deciding vote over any sale. But Tuesday's announcement said that Thomson has already agreed to abide by Reuters' arrangements for preserving news independence, and a person close to Reuters suggested that the Reuters Trust would likely support the merger. The Thomson family's holding company backs the deal, which would leave it with about 53% of a combined company. Citing the pending discussions, neither Thomson nor Reuters would talk to Barron's for this story.   Wall Street forecasts for the separate companies expected them to pull in a combined $4 billion in 2008 cash flow (before capital spending). Add half a billion dollars in savings and put a multiple of 11.5 times on that estimated cash flow, and you could get an enterprise value for Thomson-Reuters of about $47.5 billion. Adjust for $1.5 billion in new debt and almost 80 million in new shares of Thomson, and Thomson shares would be worth well more than 50 bucks apiece -- 20% over recent levels above $42.   A successful acquisition of Reuters would crown the 10-year restructuring campaign of Thomson chief exec Harrington, who plans to retire and leave Thomson-Reuters in the hands of Reuters' 47-year-old chief, Tom Glocer. For the past several years, Glocer has aggressively cut costs at Reuters, with the aim of lifting its operating-profit margin from 12% to 20% by 2010. Thomson already has those margins. And with bigger pieces of the legal and financial-data markets, a Thomson-Reuters combo might also be able to boost margins with its pricing power. That would give Thomson-Reuters shareholders -- and Bloomberg -- a run for their money.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Speaking Of Dividends: Higher Payout On Board
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   Railroad stocks gained speed last Tuesday on shareholder-friendly moves by giant CSX Corp. and on acquisition activity in the sector.   The largest rail system in the eastern U.S., the company (ticker: CSX), a Dow Jones transports component, rode to a 52-week high of 47.38 after announcing it will hike its quarterly common dividend 25% and repurchase another $1 billion worth of its stock. The enriched buyback brings the company's total current program to $3 billion (about 15% of its total market capitalization) through 2008. CSX also plans to invest $6.4 billion in operations over the next four years.   The new payout will be 15 cents a share versus 12 cents. Distribution will take place Sept. 14 for holders of record Aug. 31. The stock goes ex-dividend Aug. 29. With that payment, which makes for a 1.33% yield, the Jacksonville, Fla., company will have tripled its annual dividend in less than two years and restored it to the level it was before being slashed in July 2001 to a nickel a share. Figures are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in August 2006.   "These actions emphasize our confidence in the earnings power of CSX businesses as demand for our rail and intermodal services is robust and expected to grow," declared Chief Executive Michael J. Ward. He added that CSX remains "committed to driving shareholder value."   Standard & Poor's is less sanguine. It lowered its ratings on CSX debt, saying the "increased, debt-financed repurchase program indicates a more aggressive financial policy and contrasts with a focus on debt reduction in prior years." Moody's Investors Service, which is reviewing CSX debt for possible downgrade, said the company's plan "marks the most aggressive increase in debt for shareholder-enhancement programs among the major railroads, and comes at a time when softer economic conditions could further weaken demand for railroad transportation services."   Be that as it may, CSX anticipates record operating income and earnings per share this year, while delivering strong free cash flow,  and double-digit average increases annually through 2010.   Last week's rail rally, which extended across the border into Canada, was helped by Florida East Coast Industries' (FLA) disclosure that it will be taken private by Fortress Investment Group in a deal valued at $3.5 billion.     The visco-elastic foam in the high-end mattresses and pillows crafted by Tempur-Pedic International (TPX) was developed by NASA during the 1970s to help cushion astronauts during liftoff. On Monday, Tempur-Pedic launched a higher quarterly common dividend of eight cents a share. Distributions were begun in January at six cents. Investors of record May 31 will receive the new dividend June 14. The ex-date is May 29. Yield: 1.27%.   CEO H. Thomas Bryant said the payout boost "reflects our confidence in the company's growth prospects, as well as our strong cash flow and financial position. We are executing on our strategy to extend our global market leadership and deliver sustained, profitable growth."   The shares currently trade about three points under their 52-week high of 28.90, set April 19. In the first quarter, Tempur-Pedic repurchased 1.5 million of its shares at an average price of 25.61, for a total cost of $39.2 million. It has some $60 million remaining under its current buyback authorization.   The Lexington, Ky.-based company said capacity limitations in the face of strong consumer demand "somewhat moderated" first-quarter results, but last month it opened a new plant in Albuquerque, N.M. January-March net climbed 10.7% from a year earlier to $29.8 million, or 35 cents a share, on a 16.4% sales gain to $266 million. At wholesale, the overall mattress market is believed to be $6 billion in the U.S. and $12 billion worldwide, with the premium segment growing the fastest.   Tempur-Pedic said earlier this month that a 2005 stockholders' lawsuit should be dismissed because there's not "one single specific fact" to support allegations that it made false statements to inflate its stock price or that insider sales had been "unusual or suspicious in timing or amount."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Time To Raise A Glass To Constellation
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jay Palmer   A sure-fire cure for the common hang-over may still elude mankind, but one thing certainly can help: a rising stock.   Just ask the shareholders of Constellation Brands, the wine, beer and spirits concern. Following a disappointing earnings announcement in January, the stock tumbled 30%, from a near all-time high of 29 to under 19. Now, five months later, a partial rebound fueled by the recent announcement of an accelerated $420 million stock buyback has taken the stock back up to 23.   And as several problems still causing headaches and queasiness on Wall Street gradually are solved, still brighter times lie ahead.   A severe wine glut in Australia is showing signs of tailing off, and the company is integrating a big, recent spirits deal while also working out the kinks in both a makeover of its U.S. distribution and a new Mexican beer-importing deal.   All that will take some time. In fact, consensus among analysts is that both sales and earnings will drop at least 20% this fiscal year, ending February '08. But as the improvements kick in, earnings should turn up sharply.   Tim Ramey, an analyst for brokerage D.A Davidson, and himself owner of a vineyard in Oregon, sees profits climbing 20% in fiscal '09, to $1.75 a share. The shares, now trading at just 13.5 times that estimate, could well hit 29 in 12 to 18 months, he says.   On top of everything else, the New York-based Constellation (ticker: STZ) is well-positioned to benefit from the increasing popularity of high-end wines and spirits. "The U.S. and other major world wine markets are now undergoing some profound shifts in drinking habit [like moving to more upmarket brands], and these shifts are playing to some of the company's big strengths," says Ramey.   Constellation, with a market value of $5.5 billion, is the kind of company that the good ladies who promoted the 18th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution back in 1920 would have hated. It is the world's largest wine maker, owning a total of 50 wineries as far-flung as New York State, the West Coast, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and (in the form of partial equity stakes) Europe.   At the high end, the company's labels include such prestigious names as the Mondavi Reserves, Australia's Eileen Hardy and Canada's Inniskillin ice wines; the latter in some years sells for close to $100 a half bottle. It also owns 50% shares of Napa's famous Opus One. At the bottom of the price pyramid, Constellation makes and sells a range of what British drinkers impolitely call "plonk," including ultra-low-priced Inglenook, Almaden and Taylor New York.   The wine part of the business, branded and mass marketed together, accounts for close to 75% of total sales.   The next biggest slice, at 20%, comes from beer, although the company is not a brewer but an importer. It brings into the U.S. not only the Tsingtao and St. Pauli Girl labels, but also the far-better-known and faster-selling Mexican-made Corona and Modelo brands.   The rest of total sales comes from spirits, generally lesser known brands like Ridgemont Reserve bourbon, Paul Masson brandy, Danfield's Canadian whiskey, 99 schnapps, Kajmir vanilla liqueur and Effen vodka.   Before that portfolio really shines, the company is sure to take some more financial lumps. Constellation will probably announce a 20% drop in sales and a near- 50% drop in earnings for the current three months when it reports in late June. Each of the subsequent three quarters will also have unfavorable comparisons -- although the percentage declines will steadily grow smaller.     The biggest problem for Constellation is the impact of the Australian wine glut on the company's critical U.K. market, which accounts for about 10% of total revenues. Increasing vineyard plantings in Australia over the past decade have driven that country's grape harvest to successive record levels in 2005 and 2006. Since Australia traditionally exports the bulk of its wines to Britain, this increasing flood prevented Constellation from lifting prices to offset normal cost increases.   Worse still, it allowed an increased number of supermarkets and other middlemen to start up their own private labels. The result: an oversaturated market that sent revenues and profits plunging.   Yet a turnaround is already under way. "The huge Australian harvest came on very rapidly, producing the kind of wine glut that Barron's has been warning of for years," says Richard Sands, Constellation's CEO. "But it looks like the worst is over."   Thanks to the drought, he adds, "this year's harvest will probably be down 30% on last year. And since the drought has prevented many growers from watering the vines after picking -- something important to the following year's crop -- it's likely that, too, will be lower still. But it's hard to predict exactly how and when this will play out. There's never been a glut like this in the history of the wine business." (Barron's first warned of this overabundance in "The Coming Glut," August 3, 1998.)   Added to the turmoil in Europe, Constellation voluntarily elected to disrupt its U.S. wine sales at the same time; electing, as many other liquor companies have recently done, to revamp its sales system to cut distributors' inventory levels. While the move has and will significantly reduce the company's total U.S wine sales in the first half of the calendar year, it has been generally applauded, since it cuts stocks to mirror demand, frees up capital for distributors and improves the company's supply-chain management.   When the destocking is complete this summer, suggests D.A. Davidson's Ramey, "it will reduce the need for promotions to move excess product and give Constellation significantly more pricing power."   The beer business, for its part, was thrown into disarray when Constellation signed a new deal with Mexico's Grupo Modelo, the brewer of Corona. Previously, Constellation only had rights to import the Mexican beers to the West Coast. As of last January, however, the new joint venture with Modelo gave it rights to the entire U.S. There was inevitably some confusion, and an increase in inventory in the pipeline, both of which will dampen first-quarter returns and, to a lesser degree, the second-quarter numbers also.   "We are now in a tremendous position to really build on and market these brands across the country," notes Sands. "Though sales of the broad U.S. beer brands have been slowing or declining, sales of imported, upmarket brands have been growing. Corona is the No. 1 imported beer in the U.S., and we are in a perfect position to continue growth."   The last big problem is significantly smaller in impact but could last longer: the purchase earlier this year of Svedka vodka from its European owner for $384 million -- a high price, but far below the the $2 billion Bacardi paid to buy Grey Goose three years ago. Produced in Sweden and launched in 1998 primarily for the U.S. market, Svedka boasts a stunning track record, boosting sales by 60% in 2006 to more than one million cases and becoming one of the world's top 100 premium spirits brands.   The deal markedly increases Constellation's market share in vodka, still by far the fastest growing part of the spirits business. And it lifts Constellations sales of premium brands to about 30% of total spirits sales from 20%.   But while the deal makes strategic sense, it comes at a price. Consensus calculations suggest the purchase will be dilutive for at least the next three years, costing more in terms of interest than it will deliver in profits. The problem is that the company borrowed a good chunk of change for the deal, and it's debt is rated as "junk," the result of past acquisitions and a long-term debt load that amounts to nearly 50% of capital.   Still, the Svedka purchase fits in neatly with Constellation's push to move upmarket across its entire portfolio of wines, spirits and beers, a push designed to mirror the big ongoing upmarket swing in U.S. drinking habits.   According to CEO Sands, sales in the overall spirits market are rising by just 4% to 5% a year, but this includes zero growth at the lower price points and 10% annual growth for premium brands. "This is why the Svedka acquisition is so important and why we paid the price we did," he says. "We can and will build growth around it, putting other brands that we create or buy to ride on its coattails."     Constellation is following a similar strategy in wine, aiming to boost organic growth of such upmarket labels as Ravenswood, Jackson-Triggs, RH Phillips and Kim Crawford, and (it's assumed) continuing to explore still further acquisitions. The change, slow as it may be, will work steadily to improve both margins and sales.   "Most people don't realize it," notes Sands, "but Constellation is the No. 1 premium-wine maker in the U.S. and in the world." In value wines and so-called fighting varietals, which are wines selling for under $8 a bottle, Constellation is ranked third in that market, which is a market where sales are either falling or at best static.   But in the higher categories, up to the $15 level, the company is the biggest seller in terms of units.   "We think in terms of the market for $10 wines growing at about 10% a year and the market for $20 bottles at about 20%," says Sands. "That's where the growth is and that's where our focus is."   That's good reason for shareholders to raise a glass.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: ABN Amro Weighs Up Approaches For The Priory - Telegraph
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The Priory Group, which features a celebrity rehabilitation clinic, may be up for sale, The Daily Telegraph reports Saturday, citing banking sources.   ABN Amro Funds (ABNAF.YY), which bought the Priory Group in July 2005 for GBP875 million including debt, is weighing up several approaches for its majority stake in the mental health-care company, the newspaper says.   Bids are seen valuing the entire group, with its 42 locations, 2,000 beds and 4,500 staff, at around GBP1 billion, the newspaper says.   Bankers said the frontrunners are property companies, that want to separate the Priory's real estate assets from its health-care service, the newspaper reported.    Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9413     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 07:17 ET (11:17 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Deutsche Telekom CEO Appeals To Union On Hours,Pay Cuts-Report
Story: BERLIN (AP)--Deutsche Telekom AG's (DT) chief executive appealed for union agreement to plans to cut pay and increase hours for service workers, and said in an interview released Saturday that the company may have to sell service units if there is no deal.   The plans have prompted the first major strike against Europe's biggest telecommunications company since it was privatized more than a decade ago. Some 10,000 employees walked off the job Friday after members of the service workers' union, ver.di, voted overwhelmingly to strike.   "We have no alternative to the reform course," CEO Rene Obermann was quoted as telling the Bild am Sonntag newspaper in a preview of its Sunday edition.   "The door to talks remains open. We want a joint solution with ver.di," Obermann added, according to the report. "But if there is no solution with the union, we could be forced into sales of service operations to get costs under control; that would certainly be the worse solution for employees, and we don't want it."   Deutsche Telekom wants to transfer up to 50,000 staffers to a new service unit, dubbed T-Service, in a move that would allow the Bonn-based company to amend the employees' labor contracts to secure more hours and lower pay.   The company says it needs to transfer the workers as part of a cost-cutting plan to remain competitive. It has seen earnings tumble and market share erode amid fierce competition in the German market.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 07:03 ET (11:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Annaly's Opportunity
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jacqueline Doherty   The Federal Reserve has been no friend to Annaly Capital Management in recent years, but that could change if the economy continues to weaken in 2007, spurring the central bank to lower interest rates. Annaly, a Manhattan-based real-estate investment trust, borrows funds at short-term rates and reinvests them in mortgage-backed securities sold by the likes of Fannie Mae (ticker: FNM) and Freddie Mac (FRE). It earns the difference, or spread, between the income generated by its portfolio and its cost of capital, and pays out about 90% of its earnings in the form of dividends.   Alas, that spread is only 0.58 of a percentage point these days, following the Fed's three-year campaign to tighten credit, which has boosted the short-term federal-funds rate to 5.25% from 1%. With rates on long-dated Treasuries relatively unchanged, the yield curve has flattened or inverted for much of the past year.   Mortgage yields don't mimic the Treasury market precisely, but the difference is negligible in terms of the damage done: Annaly earned only 44 cents a share last year, down from a record $2.67 in 2002. Its dividend fell to 57 cents a share, compared with a payout of $2.67 in 2002, and its shares dropped to 15 from 21. Annaly recently traded at 15.86.   Some savvy investors now think the worst is over. "The yield curve will start to steepen in the second half of the year and continue to do so in '08 as the economy begins to slow and the Fed cuts rates," says Arnie Schneider, chief investment officer of Schneider Capital Management, which has owned shares for about a year. "If the federal- funds rate decreases by one percentage point, [the company] could probably earn close to $2."   The last time Annaly earned as much, in 2002 and '03, its stock traded up to 21 a share.   Fed policymakers left rates unchanged when they met last week, but spreads already have widened, as Annaly's first-quarter results attest. The company earned 26 cents a share before one-time gains, two cents above Wall Street expectations and 10 cents higher than a year ago. Analysts expect Annaly to earn $320 million, or $1.19 a share, on net interest income of $410 million this year, and $1.42 a share in 2008. Dividends should rise commensurately.   Like Schneider, Annaly Chairman and CEO Michael Farrell thinks the Fed's next move is down, as a deteriorating housing market threatens the broad economy. "It could be fall before we see the Fed move to lower rates, but the bond market would move ahead of that," he says.   A reduction in the fed-funds rate normally drives down short-term Treasury yields faster than long yields. Hence, Annaly's borrowing costs would fall faster and more sharply than the income earned on its investments.   At the end of the first quarter Annaly had $33 billion of repurchase agreements, or short-term borrowings, secured by the majority of its $39 billion of mortgage-backed securities. Its borrowing costs averaged 5.1%, and its yield on investments 5.68% -- hence, the 0.58-of-a-point spread. Nearly 85% of the company's repo agreements mature within 30 days, while the rate on the investment portfolio resets after 19 months (or 9.5 months, after accounting for the company's interest-rate-swap portfolio).   Current earnings estimates assume the Fed will stay on hold or cut rates by half a percentage point in the next year. But the Fed rarely cuts in such restrained fashion; to spur the economy, former Fed Chief Alan Greenspan lowered rates by 6.75 percentage points from 1989 to 1992, notes Jeremy Diamond, a managing director of the REIT.     Annaly faces several risks, chief among them the possibility that the economy will strengthen and the Fed will raise rates. If that happens, the shares could fall by as much as three dollars, says Robert Napoli, an analyst at Piper Jaffray, who has a Market Perform rating on the stock. Even if Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke stands pat, the shares could give up a dollar or so, Napoli reasons.   Mortgage prepayments could also pose a problem. When interest rates fall sharply, as in 2003, borrowers typically prepay existing mortgages and take on new loans at lower rates. If history repeats, Annaly will receive fresh cash just as interest rates head lower, capping its potential profit.   Annaly's risks -- and opportunities -- are amplified by the use of leverage, which stood at 9.8 to 1 at the end of March. For every dollar of equity, the REIT borrows another $9.80, investing it all in mortgages. Higher rates could lead to significantly higher borrowing costs.   Farrell, 56, and Wellington Denahan-Norris, 43, Annaly's chief operating officer, have maneuvered the company expertly since founding it in 1997. "History is littered with the body bags of people who try to do what we do for a living," Farrell observes.   Indeed, some investors cite the "Farrell" premium to explain why Annaly trades at a 33% premium to book value of $11.90, while peers trade at book. The combination of strong management and size give it two advantages: abundant access to credit, and better financing terms. The company currently pays about 0.05 of a percentage point under one-month LIBOR (the London Interbank Offered Rate), while similar REITs pay as much as a tenth of a percentage point over, estimates Stephen Laws, an analyst at Deutsche Bank Securities, which was involved in Annaly's secondary stock offering last year. Laws has a Buy rating.   Annaly's small asset-management division also adds ballast. While it contributed just $22 million of revenue, versus nearly $170 million of net interest income, its earnings generally are steadier than other REIT earnings and garner higher multiples.   Farrell is bearish on the economy."The country is going through a real-estate depression," he says. "It just hasn't played out yet." Low-income consumers don't have access to credit, he notes. Boomers are squeezed by college payments and the cost of caring for parents. And states and municipalities face huge pension obligations.   Farrell and his team hold just a small percentage of Annaly's shares. Yet, they haven't sold in the past two years. Perhaps they're enticed by the shares' 5% dividend yield -- or confident they can build upon the company's long-term performance. Since inception Annaly has returned 246%. In the "right" rate climate, that's only a beginning.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Profile: Hunting For Small Game
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Suzanne McGee   Talking With   Chuck Akre   Principal,   Akre Capital Management     The fox-hunting season may have wrapped up for the year, but enthusiast Chuck Akre isn't getting all misty about it. The Virginia-based investment manager is too busy trying to hunt down another kind of quarry: small companies with big competitive edges and world-class management teams.   The quest for these elusive entities may make flushing out foxes from their lairs in the Virginia countryside look simple by comparison. "The things that we look for are scarce," explains Akre. "We have to take our time and consider carefully what we will do with our cash."   That cash, meanwhile, is mounting almost daily in the coffers of FBR Small Cap Fund (ticker: FBRVX), the mutual fund that Akre has run since its inception a decade ago. In 2000 Akre and his team at Akre Capital Management became an independent entity that sub-advises the fund for FBR Mutual Funds, a Friedman Billings Ramsey unit. FBR recently reopened the fund to new capital -- for the first time in three years -- some $600 million in new assets have been allocated to the small-cap fund, which now has a total of $1.7 billion.   And today nearly a third of the fund -- some $500 million -- remains uninvested. Says Akre: "Finding new [investment ideas] is the lifeblood of this business, but we have to stick to our discipline. It's not a simple process."   He isn't kidding. To qualify for inclusion in Akre's portfolio -- only about 40 names make the cut at any one time -- a company must have the potential to post above-average returns on capital. Ideally, in Akre's eyes, that will come as a result of a regulatory edge, patent protection or other advantage that will keep competitors from nipping at their heels. He also insists on top-quality management teams. "We want them to be excellent at running the business and to see their public shareholders as partners," Akre says.   Many of Akre's favorite stocks are founded and still run by families who retain large stakes in the businesses and thus think like shareholders. A case in point: Penn National Gaming (PENN), which he discovered more than a decade ago. "When we found it, it had five off-track betting locations in Pennsylvania; today, it's the third-largest gaming-venue operator in the country," Akre says proudly.   What attracted him to that stock was the combination of the industry's growth potential and the CEO's ambition and commitment. "He had his own money on the line, and had a great sense of what the risk and the potential were -- and we were able to buy at a very modest valuation," Akre adds. The company, which today owns an array of race tracks and casinos, trades at just 11 times Akre's estimate of free cash flow for 2008 and 13 times 2007 estimated free cash flow.   Although Akre has held Penn National in the FBR portfolio for most of the fund's lifetime, he sees no reason to unload it any- time soon. Indeed, the fund's turnover is a measly few percentage points a year, and Akre will hang on to a stock even after it has moved out of conventional small-cap territory into the world of mid-caps. "When we designed the fund, having that flexibility was one thing I insisted on," he says. "We didn't want to have to cut our flowers back in order to water our weeds."   Not that Akre has cultivated many weeds. His offbeat array of small-cap stocks, dominated by gaming, specialty finance and specialty retail companies, has generated an average annual return of 19.6% for the fund in the five-year period ended March 31 -- and as high as 45.8% in some recent years.   Sustaining that record could get trickier, especially with the responsibility of putting so much new cash to work, says Laura Lutton of fund-tracker Morningstar. "It's tough to continue to do that well anyway, but you have to wonder if the fund's larger size is going to hamstring Chuck's ability to be nimble and position himself where he really wants to be," she says. "I think this fund is FBR's star offering, and their best chance for asset growth, but I want to be sure, going forward, that the investment process isn't compromised by the growth in assets."   For Akre, that's not even up for debate. FBR trustees asked him on no fewer than six occasions to consider reopening the fund, since its performance remained stellar. He eventually consented late last year, after market volatility created some fresh buying opportunities, and the fund reopened in January. "Just because we have a lot of cash doesn't mean we'll get it to work today," he says.   Certainly, Akre doesn't mind buying out-of-favor companies that meet his criteria and holding them until their problems have been resolved and the market recognizes their intrinsic value.   For instance, one of the fund's largest holdings -- nearly 3% of the portfolio -- is 99 Cents Only Stores (NDN), a beleaguered dollar-store retailer that didn't file its 10-K for the March 31, 2006, fiscal year with the Securities and Exchange Commission until this April. "Everything that could go wrong with this company, went wrong," says Akre. Management bungled the company's expansion in Texas and ran afoul of new accounting regulations. Akre started buying NDN in late summer of '04 at $13 a share, and kept buying down to 10 a share through year-end '06, convinced the company would resume its historic earnings and growth pattern. These days, the stock hovers between 13 and 15.   One of Akre's contrarian bets these days is on housing-related businesses like Pool Corp. (POOL), a swimming-pool distributor. Its business, he notes, isn't tied to new-home starts -- some two-thirds of gross profits come from remodeling and maintenance of swimming pools. Indeed, Akre began adding to his holdings of building-products companies about eight months ago, betting that homeowners no longer able to trade up would opt to buy, say, new kitchen cabinets -- from companies like American Woodmark (AMWD), another holding.   And as recent history has shown, it may be foolish to bet against Akre the contrarian.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Cerberus May Be Top Contender To Buy Chrysler Group -Report
Story: AUBURN HILLS, Michigan (AP)--Private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management LLC may be the top contender to buy DaimlerChrysler AG's (DCX) struggling Chrysler Group, according to a newspaper report Saturday.   Cerberus has been holding extensive discussions with DaimlerChrysler on a possible deal, while two other contenders - Magna International Inc. (MGA) and a Blackstone Group-led consortium - have not been involved in advanced talks since submitting bids, The Detroit News reported, citing people close to the sale process that it did not name.   A decision could be made soon on a preferred buyer for Chrysler, the newspaper said.   DaimlerChrysler spokesman Han Tjan said Saturday he could not comment on the report. A message seeking comment was left Saturday with Cerberus.   Chrysler lost $1.5 billion in 2006 and is undergoing a recovery plan that will cut 13,000 jobs in Canada and the United States and pare back production. DaimlerChrysler announced in February that all options for Chrysler are on the table, including a sale.   Analysts have said that Magna, a Canadian auto parts supplier, is the front-runner in its bid to purchase a stake of Chrysler.   Among the others reportedly interested in Chrysler is the consortium of investors led by Blackstone. Neither Blackstone nor Cerberus has confirmed its interest. Billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian, who tried to take control of Chrysler in the 1990s, also has said he would make a bid.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 11:40 ET (15:40 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Plugged In: The Moto-Nortel Connection
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   Motorola has been dominating the headlines with last week's contentious showdown between Carl Icahn and Chief Executive Ed Zander. But one of the more intriguing characters missing from that drama was Nortel Networks Chief Executive Mike Zafirovski, who was one of the key players in helping Motorola fix its storied mobile phone business earlier this decade.   Motorola (ticker: MOT) could probably use Zafirovski about now. A General Electric alumnus, he was hired by former Motorola CEO Chris Galvin and teamed with then-Chief Technology Officer Ralph Pini to lead a rebound in phones that eventually spawned the RAZR. But before the fruits of their labor were evident in 2003, the board forced Galvin out and passed over Zafirovski to recruit Zander from Silicon Valley. Both Pini and Zafirovski eventually left Motorola after Zander's arrival.   Since then, Zander has been left with a relatively bare bench when it comes to cellphone-engineering turnaround specialists. Of course, Motorola is still stocked with capable engineering talent, but designing an iconic (Moto's favorite adjective) high-margin platform on a fast-track, with Icahn breathing down Zander's neck at the same time, won't be easy.   Zafirovski, with his operations and manufacturing experience, might well have been up to the task. Instead, he finds himself leading a turnaround that is probably even more challenging than the one at Motorola.   Nortel (NT) was in a real mess when he arrived in late 2005, and he has worked diligently to straighten it out. The Canadian telecom giant doesn't make handsets but does compete with Motorola in the rapidly consolidating telecommunications infrastructure industry.   While Zander was answering to Icahn in Chicago last week, Zafirovski was basking in the relative success of his own shareholder meeting, held in Toronto several days before Motorola's. While hardly out of the woods, Nortel reported a narrower first-quarter loss than expected, slightly better revenues and improved gross margins. That didn't come as a total surprise; I wrote about the turnaround's prospects several months ago in a feature story ("Nortel's Stronger Signal," Dec. 11, 2006). Shares were trading last week around 24, up about two bucks from when the story ran.   Nortel still faces obstacles. For one thing, it's in a prickly intellectual-property battle in U.S. District Court in Marshall, Texas, the court of choice for intellectual property plaintiffs.   Last month, Nortel lost the suit, filed by Australia's QPSX, and was told to pay $28 million in damages. The trouble is, legal experts say, that the price tag could swell to three times that before it is over, including court costs, lawyers' fees and pre-judgment interest. Since Nortel is expected to earn only about $320 million in profits this year, that's a decent chunk of change. Since the ruling, Nortel has moved to dismiss the verdict and will likely appeal.   Three of Nortel's competitors -- Juniper Networks, Alcatel-Lucent and Cisco Systems -- also were sued for patent infringement by QPSX but opted to settle before going to trial. Nortel's lawyers apparently weren't as wise, but Zafirovski is on the case: Last week, the company replaced its lead outside firm with a new team of patent lawyers.   ---   E-mail: mark.veverka@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Barron's 500 -2-
Story: With 100 million iPods already in the market, unit growth could decline, says Bruce Bartlett, manager of the Lord Abbett Large-Cap Growth Fund (LALCX). The iPhone will be a big determinant of Apple's future, he says. The device, which is expected to go on sale late next month, combines an iPod, a cellphone and an Internet device.   Initial interest seems to be high, says Bartlett, whose fund owns Apple shares, "but the degree of demand will be dictated by the price point and to what degree it is subsidized [by wireless providers]." A price of $400-$500 might dampen demand, but at $250 to $350 the iPhone could be "extremely successful," he says.   If Apple sells 12 million iPhones in the higher price range, the company could generate $6 billion in incremental revenue, says Gabe Birdsall, a manager of the AIM Constellation Fund (CSTGX); Apple is the fund's biggest position. Birdsall thinks the company could double its size in three to five years, but he cautions that an iPhone flop would weigh heavily on its shares.   With a relatively high P/E, Apple isn't without risk. Second-quarter results were strong, with profits up 88%, but investors didn't celebrate because much of that gain came from lower component costs. Apple executives declined to comment.     Terex   Our fourth-place finisher isn't a household name, but it is well known among the world's mining and construction companies. Westport, Conn.-based Terex, which makes large, off-road heavy-duty mining trucks and mobile cranes, among other big machines, has benefited handsomely from the global commodity boom, says Zili Zhang, directive of quantitative research for American Century Investments.   Terex's cash-flow growth stems, in no small part, from its numerous acquisitions in the late 1990s and early 2000s; it combined companies and cut overhead, says Ron Muhlenkamp, who runs the Muhlenkamp Fund (MUHLX) and owns Terex shares.   Adding capacity this way eliminated the need to build new plants when the global boom got under way a few years ago. "Building new capacity eats up cash," Muhlenkamp says.   Ryan Amerman, an analyst at AIM Investments, concurs, noting improved efficiencies allowed operating margins to rise to 9.3% last year from 6.5% in 2005. Terex also managed to raise inventory turnover to about four times a year from 3.3 times, he says. The inventory-turn rate is a measure of how fast a company moves products out the door.   Terex's chairman and CEO, Ronald DeFeo, says the company has been able to wring cash from an "aggressive" approach to waste in the manufacturing process over the past few years. Terex also has been successful in passing along price increases from suppliers to clients.   Now that Terex has bulked up, the "next phase" is to leverage its size to increase purchasing power. "We use as much steel as BMW, but from 1,000 suppliers," DeFeo says.   If the company can extract cost savings from suppliers, that should help Terex fulfill its vow to deliver "12-12-10," or $12 billion in sales and 12% operating margins by the end of 2010. Last year, Terex reported revenue of $7.7 billion, up 24% from 2005, while earnings per share more than doubled, to $3.88.   Terex currently sells for 14.7 times 2007 consensus estimates of $5.54 per share, though its expected growth rate exceeds that P/E multiple. Yes, it is in a cyclical business, but as long as the digging and building continue around the world, Terex looks prepared to fulfill its promise.     Paccar   Anybody who has driven America's highways might recognize Paccar's products: 18-wheelers with names like Peterbilt and Kenworth that flash by hauling goods cross-country.   Paccar makes light, medium and heavy-duty trucks and engines and sells them around the world. Like Terex, Paccar's cash flow has been boosted by global growth.   In addition to strong sales growth -- revenue jumped 17% to $16.5 billion last year -- Paccar built up its cash flow by increasing inventory turns 400% and cutting expenses as a percentage of sales by 60% in the past decade, notes its chairman and CEO, Mark Pigott. More recently, it has accelerated the design process for new products so that new rigs come to market in two to three years instead of five years, he says.   The Bellevue, Wash., company's operations are less capital-intensive than those of its peers and most other heavy-industry companies, says Tony Fiore, a Standard & Poor's analyst. By outsourcing a significant percentage of components, like transmissions and engines (in the U.S.), Paccar can operate with relatively little working capital, freeing up cash for other things, he says. That has contributed to above-average returns and operating margins, he adds.   Paccar shares, up 68% in the past 12 months, now trade for about 19 times 2007 consensus estimates of $4.73 per share, down from $5.95 last year. Analysts expect North American demand to slow.   Yet Paccar managed to beat estimates handily in the first quarter, raising dividends in the process to 25 cents a share per quarter. The U.S. represents a not-insignificant 40% of Paccar's business, but the company has a long track record of outperforming and is likely to keep doing so, as long as the global economy stays strong.   ---                            Barron's 500 Methodology   Holt, a unit of Credit Suisse, uses four equally weighted measures to grade and rank the largest companies in the U.S. and Canada (as measured by  sales). For each company, Holt calculates stock-price performance relative to the Standard & Poor's 500 Index (for the 52 weeks ended April 27); the median cash-flow return on investment (CFROI) for the past three years, stripped of the effects of inflation and accounting practices; CFROI in the latest fiscal year compared to the three-year historical median, and sales growth in the latest fiscal year, adjusted for acquisitions and divestitures. For financial companies, Holt calculates cash-flow return on equity.   The firm then grades each company in all four categories: the top quintile in each category gets an A, the bottom quintile an F. Using these grades, it calculates a total grade-point average, or GPA, for each company, with 4.0 the highest. In the case of tie GPAs, the "winner" is the company with the greatest change in CFROI or cash-flow return on equity in the past year. The Barron's 500 excludes companies that are restating financial data, operating under bankruptcy protection or have delisted shares.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Putin Goes To Central Asia To Secure Russia's Energy Interests
Story: By Kadyr Toktogulov   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     ALMATY, Kazakhstan (Dow Jones)--Russian President Vladimir Putin has embarked on a seven-day tour of energy- rich Central Asia, at a time when the region is opening up to Western and Chinese investments and as talk of alternative pipelines bypassing Russia has intensified.   In the longest Central Asian tour of his presidency, Putin is attempting to secure Russia's long-term interests in the region, analysts say. The trip coincides with an energy summit in Poland that is to discuss ways to reduce Europe's energy reliance on Russia.   Putin met with Kazakh President Nursultan Nazarbayev in the Kazakh capital Astana Thursday and with Turkmen President Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov in the Turkmen capital Ashgabat Friday. The three presidents are to travel to the Caspian town of Turkmenbashi Saturday for joint talks.   After that, Putin is to return to Kazakhstan for three days to visit the Caspian port of Aktau.   "Russia wants to secure gas shipments going forward, preferably at a predictable price," Timothy Brenton, an oil and gas analyst at Renaissance Capital, said Thursday in a note. "Central Asian republics remain crucial in supporting Russia's gas balance, as domestic production is not growing sufficiently to meet domestic and export demand."   Brenton said natural gas supplies from Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan "is supporting Gazprom's business" in the former Soviet republics.   Russia exports natural gas from Central Asia through a pipeline that has an annual capacity of 60 billion cubic meters.   Putin's talks with Nazarbayev, who has been increasingly independent in his energy policies, were marked by an agreement on export prices for Kazakh natural gas processed at Orenburg gas processing plant in Russia. The Russian and Kazakh government also signed a deal on establishing a joint uranium enrichment center.   Kazakhstan has been attempting to keep Russia as well as other foreign energy partners at an equal distance regarding its oil and gas contracts.   Putin and Nazarbayev agreed to an expansion of the pipeline operated by the Caspian Pipeline Consortium that Kazakhstan uses to ship crude oil from the Tengiz oil field in western Kazakhstan operated by Chevron Corp.-led (CVX) Tengizchevroil.   No specific deal for the expansion has been signed, but it may have been linked to Kazakhstan's involvement in Russia-backed Burgas-Alexandroupolis pipeline that would take Russian and Kazakh oil bypassing the Bosphorus. The Turkish strait is already overloaded by cargo ships and has been a source of environmental concerns for the Turkish authorities.   Putin's second meeting with President Berdymukhammedov within just a few weeks is a sign that Russia wants to establish strong ties with the new leader of the country. His predecessor, Saparmurat Niyazov, who died in December, was difficult to deal with, because of his extravagant character and annoyance with Russia's dominance in its export contracts.   Turkmenistan is the second-largest natural gas producer in the former Soviet Union after Russia, with reserves of 2.8 trillion cubic meters, though the figures haven't been independently verified.   "It is remarkable that President Putin is taking a rather long trip to Central Asia where his focus will obviously be Turkmenistan," said Kaan Nazli, an analyst at Medley Global Advisors. "Russia is keen to get more say in Turkmen gas production, which is set to decline incrementally in the coming years in the absence of more investment."   Another key issue on Putin's Central Asian agenda is the construction of a pre-Caspian gas pipeline that would carry Kazakh and Turkmen natural gas supplies to Russia.   Turkmenistan has been looking for ways to transport its gas to energy-hungry China. Some Kazakh officials have suggested that Kazakhstan's territory could be used for such a project.   Russian Deputy Prime Minister Sergei Naryshkin said that the meeting between the three leaders in Turkmenbashi will focus on the construction of the Caspian pipeline, Interfax news agency reported Friday.   The pre-Caspian pipeline projects competes with a U.S.-backed trans-Caspian pipeline that would bypass Russia but is hindered by the undefined legal status of the Caspian sea.   Brenton said that Putin's two goals for the Central Asian trip included gaining support for the pre-Caspian pipeline, which would ensure Russia's dominance over Europe's energy supply, and getting guarantees from the Turkmen leadership for energy export contracts signed by Niyazov.   "Collectively, the goal of the trip is to secure for Russia a pole position in accessing energy-rich Central Asia, and consequently secure Russia's position as the major energy supplier to Europe," Brenton said.     -By Kadyr Toktogulov, Dow Jones Newswires, +7 701 726 4327; kadyr.toktogulov@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 05:00 ET (09:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
