Headline: Barron's(5/14) Asian Trader: A Dividend Culture Takes Root In Japan
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jamie Miyazaki   Investors who've decried the paltry dividends paid by cash-rich Japanese companies can now change their tune: Lehman Brothers forecasts Japanese dividend growth to be the fastest among major equity markets this year, at 20%.   Japan's real-estate investment trusts, which, like U.S. REITs, must pay out a big slice of their earnings to maintain their tax-favored status, account for a notable share of the growth. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's REIT index, sporting a roughly 3% dividend yield, has tallied a dizzying 30% rise year to date to hit a lifetime high of 2602.69 on May 8, against the Topix's paltry 2% gain.   And mobile-phone operator NTT Docomo (ticker: DCM), which raised its fiscal 2006 dividend to 4,800 yen from 4,000 yen , to recent yield of 2.3%, has comfortably outstripped the Topix year-to-date, with a 12.7% gain.   Over all, Japanese companies generating high free cash flow to equity -- cash left for shareholders after all expenses, reinvestment and debt repayments, with which companies can potentially pay dividends -- have clocked good gains this year. The telecoms have the highest free-cash-flow yield, 12.2%, in an 11-sector breakdown of Japan's equity market by Lehman Brothers.   Despite Japan's new dividend culture, the Topix's forecast of dividend yield for the 12 months ending March 2008 is a modest 1.2%, well below the 1.8% sported by the Standard & Poor's 500 in the U.S. -- a market where investors buy stocks more for price appreciation than for dividends. Indeed, the current move for higher dividends is partly a reflection of how pitiful yields are for Japan's legion of aging domestic investors clamoring for retirement income.   The Topix's dividend yield is 72% of the 10-year Japanese government bond's recent yield of 1.665%, while the S&P's yield weighs in at just 39% of that of the 10-year Treasury's. Throw in any capital appreciation with the Topix's yield, and, for some domestic investors, the mix begins to look quite appetizing.   Overseas funds have had mixed success hassling firms to speed up dividend hikes and engage in share buybacks. Dai Nippon Printing (DNPCY) recently boosted its dividends at the behest of a major investor, and a hedge fund is battling Electric Power Development (9513.JAPAN) to do the same, while Fursa Alternative Strategies failed in March to get Noritz (5943.JAPAN), a maker of heating and air-conditioning units, to raise its dividend more than tenfold.   For investors looking to play the payout trend, strategist Kazuhiro Miyake of the Daiwa Institute of Research suggests companies with high returns on equity or high yields of free cash flow to equity -- and with either an already high dividend yield or low dividend payouts relative to their sector. Blue-chip names include the diversified JFE Holdings (5411.JAPAN), shipper Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha (9107.JAPAN) and Takeda Pharmaceutical (4502.JAPAN).   Chinese equities soared last week, even as the central bank warned of a bubble. The Shanghai stock index blew past 4,000 for the first time, and volume in Chinese stocks eclipsed trading volume in the rest of Asia. So far this year, the Shanghai Composite is up 50% to 4,021. Meanwhile, Japan inched higher and Hong Kong slumped. Late in the week, investors grew concerned that China would tighten credit further, and that U.S. growth would slow.   ---   JAMIE MIYAZAKI is a reporter with Dow Jones Newswires in Tokyo.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(5/12) ABN Brazil Arm Draws Interest Amid Takeover Talk
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Carrick Mollenkamp and Jason Singer   A number of banks have contacted Barclays PLC to express an interest in ABN Amro Holding NV's main Brazilian bank operations to gauge whether that unit would ever be on the market, according to people familiar with the situation.   Barclays, which is in the midst of a contest with a European bank consortium to buy ABN, for now, has no plans to part with Banco Real if the British bank succeeds in the increasingly bitter fight for ABN. Barclays views Banco Real as one of the real growth opportunities that would come from its proposed $86.45 billion purchase of ABN, these people said.   But the inbound phone calls to Barclays add yet another twist to the ABN story. The European consortium, led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC, is reviewing its options after having its own proposed bid, valued at $97.71 billion, turned away by ABN a week ago.   ABN plans to schedule a court-ordered shareholder meeting to vote on the sale of its U.S. LaSalle bank to Bank of America Corp. But Bank of America is suing ABN in federal court in the U.S. to enforce its contract to buy LaSalle. Ahead of Bank of America's lawsuit, which was filed May 4 in U.S. federal court in the Southern District of New York, the consortium or RBS, through intermediaries, sent out feelers to Bank of America to see if there might be a way to accommodate it, though no specifics were discussed, according to people familiar with the situation. One possible avenue could have been to portion out LaSalle between RBS and Bank of America, but the feelers didn't lead to any action and the lawsuit was filed.   Spokespeople for RBS and Bank of America declined to comment.   Friday, consortium partner Fortis NV, a Dutch-Belgian concern, reported first-quarter results but offered little information on the consortium's next move. A Fortis official said that it, RBS and partner Banco Santander Central Hispano SA would update the market before the ABN shareholder meeting or before May 27. The consortium on April 25 made a proposed offer of 39 euros a share for ABN and has 30 days to provide an update under Dutch corporate law.   One of ABN's prime assets is Banco Real and the telephone calls to Barclays highlight the fact that any number of banks foreign to Brazil would prize the bank. In total, ABN's Latin America operations account for about 17% of its revenue. Globally, banks have increased their focus on the so-called BRIC countries -- Brazil, Russia, India and China -- to take advantage of these markets' demand for banking services, especially as growth slows in home markets. David Hendler, an analyst at research firm Credit Sights Inc., said Banco Real would be sought after because few independent Brazilian banks are interested in selling. Barclays declined to comment on Banco Real.   One potential buyer would be Brazil's Banco Itau Holding Financeira SA, another of Brazil's large banks. A Banco Itau spokesman said the bank always evaluates market opportunities that create shareholder value.   Banco Itau is 7.4% owned by Bank of America. If a purchase of ABN's Brazilian business would help Barclays clinch its deal for ABN, that would also benefit Bank of America. Bank of America declined to comment.   ---   Valerie Bauerlein contributed to this article.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:00 ET (04:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Takeover Or "Take Under?"
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jacqueline Doherty   The Dolan family, majority owners of Cablevision Systems, knows how to create drama. Its attempt to take the cable-television provider private -- this time for $36.26 a share -- once again has sparked an uproar among other investors who think the bid undervalues the company by as much as $10 a share. If it succeeds, critics argue, the family of Chairman Charles Dolan, 80, and his son, CEO James Dolan, 52, will capture more than $2 billion of value that would otherwise enrich Cablevision's public holders.   Our bet: The largest investors of Cablevision (ticker: CVC) will successfully block the transaction. Either the Dolans will raise their offer or the deal will unravel, leaving shares to rise in tandem with the company's improving cash flow in the next few years.   "Cablevision deserves a much higher price," says John Linehan, manager of the T. Rowe Price Value Fund (TRVLX), which owns the stock. "They're trying to steal this company from under our noses."   Mario Gabelli of Gamco Investors (GBL), another vocal critic, owns 20 million, or 7%, of Cablevision's shares. In a blog entry in January, Gabelli implied he'd consider a deal valued at $36 a share. But since then, Cablevision's stellar results and the rising value of its assets have made it more valuable, he says. Gabelli figures the private-market value of Cablevision is $51 a share, but declines to say what he would accept from the Dolans.   If the Dolans were to allow a public bidding process, Cablevision likely would attract interest from industry giants Time Warner Cable (TWC) and Comcast (CMCSA). Though the Dolans and other Cablevision representatives declined to comment, the family previously has said it is not interested in selling to a third party. Because almost all of its 57 million shares have super-voting rights, other shareholders can't force a sale. The Dolans' shares represent 20% of the economic interest in the company but 70% of the voting rights.   In their bid to acquire Bethpage, N.Y.-based Cablevision, the Dolans won't invest new money, but contribute their existing equity, valued at $2.1 billion, to a new company established to complete the acquisition. This new company and its affiliates will assume Cablevision's debt and raise about $8.5 billion of new debt to fund the purchase of Cablevision's remaining 235 million shares.   Granted, this strategy will increase the Dolans' risk; the new company will be highly leveraged, with about $2.1 billion of equity supporting $20 billion of debt. Its debt load will be about 10 times Cablevision's expected cash flow, measured by Ebitda, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, of $2 billion this year.   Unless the Dolans inject more equity, they can't raise their bid much because of Cablevision's inability to take on still more debt. But analysts assume Ebitda will grow by about 10% a year, suggesting the possibility of a higher bid down the road.   Cablevision's Ebitda is expected to increase to $2.3 billion in 2008 from $2 billion this year, according to Thomson Financial. At that point, the company theoretically could support $23 billion of debt, applying the same multiple of 10 times Ebitda. That extra $3 billion equates to $10 a share.   "We'd hang in until [the Dolans] force us out," says Christopher Marangi, an analyst with Gabelli.     What would Cablevision be worth if its sundry parts -- including the cable system, several cable networks, New York's Madison Square Garden and the New York Knicks and Rangers -- were sold off separately? The company recently announced the sale to Comcast of its 60% stake in the SportsChannel Pacific Associates and its 50% stake in SportsChannel New England -- all for a higher-than-expected $570 million. Marangi estimates Cablevision's parts are worth $48 a share now and could command as much as $58 next year as results improve.   Some analysts value the company on the basis of price to free cash flow, or operating cash flow minus capital expenditures. Craig Moffett, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, sees free cash flow rising to $5 a share by 2010. At 10 times that figure -- a fair multiple, he says -- the stock could be worth 50.   Cablevision's public holders might be pacified if they can participate in any profits the Dolans reap by selling company assets in a particular time period. Such a clause reportedly was discussed in earlier negotiations. Also, non-family holders might be willing to accept warrants or equity.   The Dolans could raise their offer by selling off a business or two, using the proceeds to increase the payout to other holders. Gabelli has said he might go to court to invoke dissenters' rights, which would allow the courts to assign a fair value to the company by which the Dolans would have to abide.   After rejecting earlier, lower bids from the family, a special committee of Cablevision's independent directors approved the latest offer. The committee required a majority of the minority shareholders to approve the deal, however. Altogether, owners of about 120 million of Cablevision's 292 million shares must vote in favor, though the Dolans can walk if holders of more than 10% of the public shares object.   The Dolans' supporters note the deal price represents an 11% premium to the stock's price before the current offer, and a 52% premium to price of the shares in October, before the family's first bid. Proponents also say Cablevision faces a growing threat from Verizon Communications (VZ), the telecom provider, which is stringing fiber throughout its territories to provide voice, data and video services to its customers. Verizon has rolled out service in more than 20% of Cablevision's markets and could become a more fearsome competitor.   Cablevision expects basic subscriber growth to climb 1% to 2% this year, versus 3.3% in '06. Client turnover grew in the first quarter, a sign Verizon is making headway, says Jason Bazinet, a Citi analyst who thinks the Dolans' offer will succeed. Others counter that Cablevision will win telephone and business customers from Verizon.   The Dolans' offer values the company at about $22 billion, or more than 10 times this year's expected Ebitda. Comcast and Time Warner Cable command only nine times Ebitda. But one industry insider notes most cable owners believe their stocks are undervalued and would like to believe their companies merit a multiple closer to 12. Time Warner Cable and Comcast, he adds, would likely pay up to 12 times Ebitda to purchase Cablevision's assets.   Historically, cable deals have been valued on the basis of subscribers. The Dolans would pay about $5,200 per "sub," while Comcast and Time Warner Cable trade for roughly $4,000 per sub. But the latter companies are unlikely to be purchased, whereas Comcast recently bought a small Princeton, N.J., cable property for about $6,000 per sub.   Cable investors who opt to sell to the Dolans might want to redeploy their proceeds in other media stocks. Moffett has a 12-month target of $35 on Comcast and $48 on Time Warner Cable, which are about two years behind Cablevision in rolling out their triple-play of voice, data and video services. Other undervalued issues include Time Warner (TWX), Sprint Nextel (S), Viacom (VIA) and News Corp. (NWS).   If the latest deal fails, Cablevision's stock could fall by several dollars. But in a year or two, it could be 10% to 20% higher as the company's fundamentals improve.   As they say in the business, stay tuned.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: TOC's Management Buyout Fails Amid Rising Share Price-Kyodo
Story: TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Leading building firm TOC Co. (8841.TO) said Saturday its management buyout bid has failed as its share price rose after a major shareholder resisted the attempt by saying the offer price was too low, Kyodo News reported.   The TOC management acquired a total of about 10 million shares during the buyout bid, far below its target of 54 million. TOC will remain listed on the First Section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange as a result.   TOC conducted the tender offer with help from foreign financial institutions between April 9 and May 11, offering to buy each share for 800 yen.   But K.K. Davinci Advisors, a real estate investment company that holds a stake of nearly 10% in TOC, argued the offer price should be raised and said it would launch a takeover bid to buy TOC shares at 1,100 yen if the TOC leadership approves it.   The TOC management has rejected the proposal.   However, amid the developments, the price of TOC stock has risen on the market, ending Friday at 1,021 yen, up 3 yen from the previous day.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 01:15 ET (05:15 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Barron's Online: A World Of Profits
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Johanna Bennett   Despite a slowing domestic economy, the nation's biggest corporations still have what it takes to keep the bears at bay, thanks to profits from abroad.   It's true that earnings growth among the largest U.S. companies has slowed compared with the big gains of a year ago. But first-quarter operating profits generated by companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index generally beat the expectations, helping to lift stock prices higher in recent weeks.   And things can get better.   Early estimates suggest that earnings growth generated by big U.S. companies will improve as the year continues, perhaps returning to double digits by the fourth quarter. And some Wall Street pundits say major market indexes can rise right along with them.   Yet much of the improvement to corporate bottom lines is coming from overseas operations, not from here at home, where economic growth slowed to a paltry 1.3% during the first quarter.   This should give export-driven, large-cap stocks such as Caterpillar (ticker: CAT) and 3M (MMM) an advantage over the stocks of small, U.S.-dependent companies.   "We talk about a global economy, well here it is," says David Dropsey, an analyst with Thomson Financial. "Big U.S. companies have positioned themselves to serve the world. If not, we would not have good earnings growth right now."   Last year, companies in the S&P 500 got 48% of their revenues from outside the U.S., up from 35% in 2002, according to Standard & Poor's. And sometime this year, that figure should hit 50%, says Howard Silverblatt, senior index analyst for S&P.   A weak U.S. dollar has made U.S. products cheap in foreign markets. Plus, fast-growing economies in China, Brazil, Russia and India are spurring demand for heavy equipment, basic materials and consumer goods such as sneakers, fast food and televisions.   Yet in the U.S., a slumping housing market and weak automobile sales have taken a lot of air out of the U.S. economy.   In 2007, the U.S. gross domestic product (GDP) should climb 2.1%, or half as fast as the broader global economy, according to Goldman Sachs.   Still, in 2007, profits generated by companies in the S&P 500 should climb 7% compared to 2006. International operations should generate half of those gains, says Barry James, president of James Investment Research. General Electric (GE), says in 2007 more than half of its revenue could come from outside the U.S. for the first time ever.   Little wonder that Goldman Sachs last week recommended a basket of 34 U.S. companies that generate 65% of their sales from outside the U.S. Up 13.2% year-to-date, the index, which includes Schering-Plough (SGP) and Colgate-Palmolive (CL), has dramatically beaten the Standard & Poor's 500's 6% gains so far this year.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Cerberus May Be Top Contender To Buy Chrysler -Report
Story: (Updates with Cerberus spokesman declining comment on report.)     AUBURN HILLS, Mich. (AP)--Private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management LLC may be the top contender to buy DaimlerChrysler AG's (DCX) struggling Chrysler Group, according to a newspaper report Saturday.   Cerberus has been holding extensive discussions with DaimlerChrysler on a possible deal, while two other contenders - Magna International Inc. (MGA) and a Blackstone Group-led consortium - haven't been involved in advanced talks since submitting bids, The Detroit News reported, citing people close to the sale process that it didn't name.   A decision could be made soon on a preferred buyer for Chrysler, the newspaper said.   DaimlerChrysler spokesman Han Tjan said Saturday he couldn't comment on the report. Peter Duda, a spokesman for Cerberus, said Saturday that the firm doesn't comment on market speculation.   Chrysler lost $1.5 billion in 2006 and is undergoing a recovery plan that will cut 13,000 jobs in Canada and the United States and pare back production. DaimlerChrysler announced in February that all options for Chrysler are on the table, including a sale.   Analysts have said that Magna, a Canadian auto parts supplier, is the front-runner in its bid to purchase a stake of Chrysler.   Among the others reportedly interested in Chrysler is the consortium of investors led by Blackstone. Neither Blackstone nor Cerberus has confirmed its interest. Billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian, who tried to take control of Chrysler in the 1990s, also has said he would make a bid.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 14:29 ET (18:29 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Kia Motors Plans To Tighten Security After Alleged Tech Leak
Story: SEOUL (AP)--Kia Motors, South Korea's second-largest automaker, said Saturday it plans to beef up security in response to an alleged leak of production technology to China.   "Kia Motors Corp. views any threats to its brand and technology as a very serious matter," the company said in a statement.   "The company is planning to expand the depth of security solutions in all divisions of the company and strengthen its employee security education program," Kia said.   Prosecutors said Thursday that they have indicted seven current and former employees of the Hyundai-Kia Automotive Group over alleged technology leaks to Chinese automakers.   The group consists of Hyundai Motor Co. (005380.SE), South Korea's largest automaker, and its affiliate Kia (000270.SE).   Together they form the world's sixth-largest automotive group and aspire to become the fifth biggest by 2010. Kia has one factory in China and is building another.   Prosecutors said in a statement that five former Hyundai-Kia employees working at an auto-consulting firm in Seoul last year allegedly obtained core technology for the manufacture of a sport utility vehicle and a new car, code named "HM," from two current Hyundai-Kia employees.   The five allegedly leaked the technology to a Chinese carmaker in return for $248,000, prosecutors said. They also allegedly tried to leak technology to another Chinese automaker, according to prosecutors.   All seven were charged with violating laws that protect business secrets and guard against unfair competition, the prosecutors said. Six of them were also charged with breach of trust.   If found guilty, the accused potentially face up to 10 years in prison.   Prosecutors said they launched the investigation in April after a tip-off from South Korea's National Intelligence Service.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 01:25 ET (05:25 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Tracing Steel's Fiery Ascent
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Interview With Michelle Applebaum   Michelle Applebaum Research     When it comes to covering the steel industry, Michelle Applebaum is in a league of her own. She followed the sector in good times during her 22-year tenure as a research analyst and managing director at Salomon Brothers, and she has stuck with it during the bad times. Through it all, she has regularly topped Institutional Investor magazine's annual list of the best-of-the-best researchers on Wall Street. Since 2003 she has headed up Michelle Applebaum Research in Chicago, continuing to offer institutional and industry clients the same cogent advice and compelling analysis that has always made her a standout. And with the good times back, she has a lot to say.     Barron's: What's your outlook for steel stocks?   Applebaum: Over all, our outlook is conservatively upbeat. The weak pockets of the U.S. economy are automotive and housing and they are definitely taking their toll on steel. It's visible. The type of steel that goes into those products, flat-rolled steel, is seeing a decline in demand in those sectors. But a lot of flat-rolled steel also goes into nonresidential uses -- office buildings and hospitals and so on. There is a tremendous amount of capital goods demand right now and we are seeing peak levels of demand -- all-time record demand -- for a lot of different products. Also, there is a market-share shift that is getting lost in the translation.     Q: How's that?   A: In the U.S., foreign steel can range from 15% to 35% of the market. Now, foreign steel is down to between 15% and 18% of domestic consumption. The difference is made up by domestic companies. The pie might be getting smaller, but then the domestic piece of the pie gets bigger. We are seeing a slower market in the U.S., but the strength of the overseas market is pulling steel out of the U.S. That's creating opportunities for domestic producers to step up. Domestic shipments and domestic demand are looking much stronger going into the second quarter, which is usually the peak period for consumer-durable markets, than they were in the fourth quarter.     Q: Isn't that at odds with U.S. Steel's forecast?   A: United States Steel [ticker: X] has a couple of issues to contend with. They've had some cost increases. They also have a big tube business [used in drilling oil and gas wells], and that's been weaker than it had been. We've seen an inventory overhang on the tube business for about six months now. It doesn't seem to be abating just yet. Then its European operations have some cost pressures. U.S. Steel's earnings will likely stay flat in the second quarter after they reported a big surprise in the first. The market was looking for $1.85 and we were looking for $1.80; they came out with $2.30 a share. It was a relatively clean number.     Q: So their issues are specific to U.S. Steel and not the steel industry in general?   A: Yes. We would expect companies like Nucor [NUE] to be up but not by a huge amount. The mini-mills had cost pressures in the month of April because there was an overrun on scrap. That's backed off, so May will be a good month, and June will be a better month for both Nucor and Steel Dynamics [STLD]. Pricing for hot-rolled coil has improved from a low of $5.25 on average early in the first quarter to $5.75 a ton now. There is an awful lot of steel that is sold on contract, and contract prices unilaterally were up for the calendar year. In overview, we are looking for increasing domestic market share and pricing opportunities as steel imports decline and prices are higher offshore. We are seeing record prices for a whole bunch of steel products overseas.     Q: Such as?   A: Structural and bar steel, for example. They are used to support construction, and they are hitting all-time pricing highs. They are selling out in the U.S. as pressures from imports have all but disappeared. It's ironic, because the industry talks about the impact of imports, particularly from China, and what you don't hear about a lot is the volatility in import prices, and the impact this has on steel buyers and the economy. Import prices are far more volatile than domestic prices. High import prices have put pressure on domestic companies to raise prices. There has been more discipline on raising prices this cycle than we saw in prior years. Nucor is the price leader in long products [like bar, rod and structural items, rather than flat], which are more than half their sales, and they have raised prices but by a lot less than the market could have given them. They are working hard to try to keep construction costs for their customers stable, and so you give them some credit for that.     Q: Hasn't consolidation contributed to pricing strength?   A: Not in the way you would think. The hidden benefit from consolidation is the operating flexibility that it brings to the integrated mills. An issue in operating a steel mill is the blast furnace. Blast furnaces can be efficiently run in only two ways: on or off. In the 1980s, the domestic industry downsized from about 150 million tons of capacity to 120 millions tons. The smaller, less-efficient blast furnaces were all shuttered permanently, and it left most of the domestic industry with two or three blast furnaces per company. The companies either had to run flat out or run at very inefficient levels. What consolidation has done is: Instead of running on three blast furnaces, where they would have to cut a third of their capacity if they cut anything, they are running on as many as 12 blast furnaces. It offers degrees of freedom, where a company can run at a 92% operating rate or 3%. That's a benefit that is fairly invisible to the investing public. About three decades ago the industry actually had that operating flexibility, but for most of my lifetime it has not.   The other big change in the industry is Nucor. Nucor is now one of the largest domestic producers of steel. Nucor always had a policy of no layoffs and was historically the low-cost producer, which made it difficult for them to cut production. But they have evolved with the help of a production-oriented compensation scheme with their workers and have shown greater production discipline. Nucor was cutting production in the fourth quarter along with the big integrated mills. It's a real change in how the industry operates.     Q: Do you favor companies that are more vertically integrated and have access to raw materials?   A: I prefer companies that are more consistently profitable, period. If they are profitable because they do a good job on the raw materials by taking them out of the ground and turning them into steel, more power to them. But if they're more profitable and don't have any raw materials, I'm going to like those companies, too. A good example is Nucor. Nucor is as nonintegrated as a company could get, yet they have, because they are not integrated, a very tight rein on their costs. When Katrina hit and gas prices skyrocketed, very few of the integrated companies had hedges in place. The interesting point is that before the gas-price runup, Nucor's natural-gas cost per ton of steel shipped was only $5, while the integrateds' cost per ton was $35. Nucor was hedged for the next 18 months. The week before Katrina, the average cost of natural gas per ton of steel shipped was $35 for the integrated companies, seven times Nucor's cost, which was only $5. Nucor has had a better focus on controlling costs, and it is true for Steel Dynamics, as well.     Q: Among domestic companies, which do you favor?   A: Over all, we like the growth prospects for the industry. Everyone is throwing off huge cash flow. Debt's being paid down and pensions are being fully funded. But the opportunities for capital redeployment and the skill sets for the redeployment vary tremendously. Two stocks at the top of my list are Reliance Steel & Aluminum [RS] and Nucor. Both are growth companies masquerading in cyclical clothing. Both have grown their top lines about 20% since 2000. Both have grown their bottom lines significantly more than that. If you hold the debt constant for the next five years, you could easily see both companies funding growth in the 10% to 12% range totally from internal cash flow and earnings per share of a similar amount. Nucor has had a compound average growth rate in excess of 20% every year since 2000. They have just announced a huge acquisition of Harris Steel, which is not a steel company but a buyer and fabricator of steel. It is exciting because it is a different kind of acquisition for Nucor. The company in the past has been reluctant to expand into its customers' business. It's also paid a healthy multiple for Harris. It was over six times cash flow, which might not seem a rich multiple but is compared to the pennies on the dollar acquisitions that they've done historically.     Q: Is this the start of a trend?   A: I expect to see more growth in the downstream side of the business: metal bending and fabricating and metal buildings. Just take rebar fabrication. The three largest players in that business are roughly 35% of that market. It is a very fragmented market. So there are a lot of opportunities for other significant acquisitions, and that is just one market. Metal buildings would be another; pipe would be another. Distribution, potentially another. Nucor has a unique niche that should allow it to grow through acquisitions.     Q: And the case for Reliance?   A: Reliance is a steel distributor. They also provide logistics. Reliance grows through acquisitions, and they acquire well-run private companies. They went public in 1994 with just under a half-billion dollars in sales, and this year their sales are projected to reach $7 billion. They've made 40 acquisitions since 1994. They are more profitable than other distributors, and I need to make my spreadsheet columns wider for them because they have double-digit margins and nobody else does.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Sonatrach Gains 27.6% Voting Rights In Energias de Portugal
Story: LISBON (Dow Jones)--EDP-Energias de Portugal SA (EDP.LB) said Algerian State oil and gas company Sonatrach now has 27.6% of its voting rights.   In a regulatory filing late Friday, EDP said the change was a result of a shareholders agreement with state holding Parpublica - Participacoes Publicas SGPS SA and state-controlled bank Caixa Geral de Depositos SA.   Sonatrach, which already owned 2% of EdP, can now vote with a total of 27.6% with the addition of the 20.54% and 4.98% from Parpublica and Caixa Geral de Depositos, respectively.   The shareholders agreement was signed in March, when EdP and Sonatrach also announced a partnership in certain gas and power generation businesses.   Also in March, Sonatrach was given the green light by the Portuguese government to increase its stake in EdP to 5% from its current 2%.     -By Filipa Cunha, Dow Jones Newswires; +351-21-3191863; filipa.cunha@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 08:26 ET (12:26 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Tech Trader: Why Disk-Drive Makers Have Years To Run
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tiernan Ray   Reports of the disk-drive business' demise have been greatly exaggerated.   Since the beginning of the year, the No. 1 and No. 2 drive makers -- Seagate Technology (ticker: STX) and Western Digital (WDC) -- have seen their stocks decline 16% and 11% respectively, on worries that personal-computer sales are slowing substantially.   Some analysts have even suggested that the newer kind of computer chip known as "flash" memory could completely replace drives in personal computers -- and put Western and Seagate out of business.   But PC sales are doing just fine, and flash -- in great part owing to its cost -- is not going to replace disk drives globally for years to come.   Once investors come to appreciate those facts, Western Digital shares could appreciate another 20% or more from a recent price of $18.10 per share.   Western is cheaper than Seagate by a wide margin, trading at a two-year-low price-to-earnings multiple of about 9.4 times the next four quarters' estimated profit per share -- below its five-year median of 11.6 times, while Seagate is near its median of 12.2 times.   "Western has an attractively valued stock for a company that is one of the premier players in a market that's set to grow at least 10% a year for several years," says Citigroup analyst Paul Mansky, referring to the expected ramp-up in disk-drive unit sales.   Mansky thinks that Western Digital is "a technology laggard by design," and that some investors underestimate Western Digital's strategy of gaming the technology curve to turn in profits and steady cash flow.   The secret is that the drive business is itself less cutthroat and less cutting edge than it was back in the 1990s.   The list of drive makers who control most of the industry's output has shrunk from nine players six years ago to just seven, as Seagate acquired competitor Maxtor, which had previously bought Quantum's (QTM) hard-drive business.   That's reduced competition over all, which is a good thing, but it's also heightened the contrast in approach taken by the top two competitors.   Seagate, which sells about a third of the industry's units, is generally regarded by investors and analysts as the technology leader.   Investors at the moment are worried that recent forecasts from both Western Digital and Seagate suggest another round of price cuts amid slowing personal computer sales. Western last month said June-quarter profit will be substantially below expectations despite rising revenue, a sure sign that margins are contracting as prices fall.   A glance at some market data shows, however, that not only are PCs selling better than expected, but the trends that are pressuring prices may also play to Western Digital's laggard approach over the long term.   The global PC market is "healthy" and will likely grow at a stable 11.1% this year over last, says IDC's director of PC research, Loren Loverde.   Global PC sales rose a better-than-expected 10.1% in the first quarter, faster than the 8.5% forecast, according to PC analyst Mikako Kitagawa with research firm Gartner.   A good chunk of that came from emerging markets such as Eastern Europe -- just the place one would expect to see cheap trailing-edge technology of the kind Western offers, which can bring down the overall bill of materials for a PC.   Furthermore, sales growth of notebook computers far outpaces desktops these days as laptops become the new mainstream machine. Laptops probably rose 30% in the first quarter, versus a mere 1% for desktops, says Kitagawa.   That's good for Western Digital, because it means the priority in computing is to achieve nearly equivalent storage capacity in a 2.5-inch notebook drive as in a 3.5-inch desktop drive, but at the same price   Such drives require not cutting-edge technology, says John Rydning, head of disk-drive research at IDC, but simply repurposing the same trailing-edge desktop technology.   Perhaps that's why Western Digital's shipment of notebook drives more than doubled in the March quarter, year over year, to 15% of its total shipments, far faster than the company's overall 30% rise in drive shipments.   For all its low-tech expertise, Western Digital has been profitable the last five years after running deep losses in the 1990s, and it has been adding cash to its balance sheet every quarter and now has roughly $4 per share in cash and no debt.   With those steady cash flows, the company could actually be a takeout target for leveraged-buyout shops, opines Citigroup's Mansky.   To be sure, another concern haunting drive stocks these days is the fear that flash-memory chips, made by Korean giant Samsung, among others, will replace disks. Flash chips are smaller and lighter, and they use less power than disks.   But flash chips are also 20 times as expensive for equal storage capacity, says Citigroup's Mansky. That means there's no way flash is going to be economical any time soon for all those laptops that have to match desktops in price, especially in emerging markets.   Another quarter-billion PCs will be sold this year, estimates Loverde, albeit at prices that continue to fall. Someone's got to build and sell drives to fit those prices. Western Digital's low-cost-laggard strategy is the right approach for such economics.   And as worries about flash chips abate and investors realize disk drives are not going away, the disk-drive maker's stock may cease to be a laggard.   ---   E-mail: tiernan.ray@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Crt Confirms Allied Joint Reorganization Plan
Story: DECATUR, Ga., May 12 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Allied Holdings, Inc. announced today that the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Northern District of Georgia yesterday issued a ruling confirming Allied's Joint Plan of Reorganization filed by Allied, affiliates of Yucaipa and by the Teamsters National Automobile Transportation Industry Negotiating Committee. Allied expects its Joint Plan to become effective prior to June 1, once all closing conditions of the plan have been met. As previously announced, at Allied's option, it may convert its current debtor-in-possession credit facility into exit financing, subject to certain conditions.   After Allied's confirmation hearing yesterday, the Honorable C. Ray Mullins issued his ruling affirming that the Company had met all of the necessary statutory requirements to confirm its Joint Plan of Reorganization and exit from Chapter 11. Judge Mullin's ruling also applies to all of Allied's wholly owned subsidiaries in the U.S. that filed for Chapter 11 protection. Each of those subsidiaries is expected to emerge from Chapter 11 alongside Allied prior to June 1.   Current holders of Allied's common stock, which has recently traded on the Pink Sheets under the symbol "AHIZQ.PK," will not receive any distributions under the Joint Plan of Reorganization. These equity interests will be canceled upon the effectiveness of the Joint Plan and the unsecured creditors of Allied will receive the new common stock to be issued in the reorganization. As set forth in the Joint Plan, these new shares of common stock will be subject to a number of transfer restrictions. Accordingly, the Company urges caution be exercised with respect to investments in its existing equity securities and any of its liabilities and other securities.     About Allied Holdings     Allied Holdings, Inc. is the parent company of several subsidiaries engaged in providing distribution and transportation services of new and used vehicles to the automotive industry. The services of Allied's subsidiaries span the finished vehicle continuum, and include car-hauling, intramodal transport, inspection, accessorization and dealer prep. Allied, through its subsidiaries, is the leading company in North America specializing in the delivery of new and used vehicles.     Forward-Looking Statements     Statements included in this press release that are not strictly historical are "forward-looking" statements. Such statements include, without limitations, any statements containing the words "believe," "anticipate," "estimate," "expect," "intend," "plan," "seek," and similar expressions. These forward-looking statements involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause Allied's actual results to differ materially from those suggested by the forward-looking statements and are beyond the Company's ability to control or predict.   These risks include, but are not limited to, the following: the Company's ability to consummate the Joint Plan of Reorganization; the Company's ability to satisfy the conditions under the DIP facility necessary for exit financing; the highly competitive nature of the automotive distribution industry; dependence on the automotive industry and ongoing initiatives of customers to reduce costs; loss or reduction of revenues generated by the Company's major customers or the loss of any such customers; the variability of OEM production and seasonality of the automotive distribution industry; the Company's highly leveraged financial position; the Company's ability to obtain financing in the future; the Company's ability to fund future capital requirements; increased costs, capital expenditure requirements and other consequences of the Company's aging fleet of Rigs as well as Rig purchasing cycles; dependence on key personnel; and the availability of qualified drivers.   Additional information concerning the risks and uncertainties that could cause differences between actual results and forward-looking statements is included in Allied's Securities and Exchange Act filings, including its Form 10-Q for the quarter ended September 30, 2006. Allied cautions readers not to place undue reliance on the forward-looking statements and Allied also disclaims any obligation to update or review forward-looking statements, except as may be required by law.   Investors and other interested parties can obtain information about Allied's Chapter 11 filing on the Company's website at www.alliedholdings.com/reorg. Court filings, claims information and Allied's Joint Plan of Reorganization are available at www.administar.net/allied.   NOTE: For additional information about Allied, please visit our website at www.alliedholdings.com.   SOURCE Allied Holdings, Inc.   /CONTACT: Thomas H. King, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, +1-404- 687-5905 /Web site: http://www.alliedholdings.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 14:52 ET (18:52 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Follow-Up: Buyout Or Not, This Magic Carpet Flies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   The fact is, the company already has a sizable amount of long-term debt, about $2.7 billion, and a leveraged buyout would almost certainly drop its debt rating to junk; Moody's Investors Service now rates it Baa3, its lowest investment-grade rank. That would virtually end its strategy of growing through acquisitions, because of the higher costs of borrowing.   That doesn't mean private-equity firms won't be snooping around, says Keith Hughes, an analyst at Atlanta-based SunTrust Robinson Humphrey Capital Markets, who has a price target of 103 on Mohawk. But Mohawk is an unlikely candidate, he says, and management seems determined to remain independent.   The company's first-quarter earnings of $1.32 a share beat analysts' estimates, and it has forecast a second-quarter profit of $1.51 to $1.60 a share, as the strength of its Belgian maker of laminate flooring continues to offset the tough U.S. environment.   So forget the buyout baloney. Focus on value and mull whether Mohawk's share price has found a floor.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Streetwise: Pricing Power
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   Economists call them giffen goods, items that become more desirable as their price rises. Economics literature is inconclusive about whether they truly exist. (Do the hedge funds that charge the most become the hardest to get into, or vice versa?) But the market lately has been hinting that high-priced stocks are enjoying an appeal all their own.   Today, there are probably more stocks with prices above $100 per share than ever before. According to numbers furnished byStandard & Poor's, as of Thursday there were 34 stocks in the S&P 500 priced in the triple-digits. You have to go back to 1999 and before that, 1997, to find as many as 27 stocks priced above $100 at any year's end.   In a related pattern, the number of stock splits among large companies this year is running at less than half the long-term average. Only six S&P 500 companies have announced stock splits in 2007, well off the 1979-2006 annual average of 59. The last time so few splits occurred: 2003, when legions of stocks had been ground down to mere nubs by the bear market.   There are a few things driving these phenomena, including mechanical factors. Electronic trading and low-cost commissions have made trading higher-priced stocks less cumbersome and costly than in the past. And retail investors -- who love to see their stocks split, even though it's like changing a $10 bill for two fives -- are a less-active constituency in the markets today. All this aside, it seems higher-priced stocks are more in favor because they confer some corporate prestige, and because they have performed better.   At Barron's request, the researchers at Bespoke Investment Group put together a portfolio of all S&P 500 stocks that were priced at $100 a share -- or more -- a year ago, and then added to it any stock that attained $100 in subsequent months. The "$100 club" portfolio returned 20.6% in the year through Wednesday, versus 15.4% for the overall S&P 500. That's a substantial (if short-term) outperformance for stocks that had already gotten to the century mark before they were "bought."   The current roster of three-digit stocks features several bellwethers of market health and investor risk appetite, most notably Google (ticker: GOOG), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME). Among the strongest stocks of the past few years, they may well have invested a bit of cache into the unsplit, high-priced stock.   The broader high-priced list indicates the way this bull market has transitioned into a momentum phase, where what has worked for the past couple of years continues to attract performance-chasing investment dollars. Energy, real-estate and capital markets stocks are well-represented, as are a couple of cult-of-personality stocks loved largely for their CEOs, like Apple (AAPL) and Sears Holdings (SHLD).   Most of the rest are part of what might be called the materials-infrastructure-industrial-transport complex, driven by the commodity boom and the emerging-market development frenzy. Take that as a warning, if you like, about the maturity of that particular market theme.   The leadership of high-priced shares also hints at the advancing maturity of the bull market generally. In 2003, in the initial mad thrust of this bull phase, there was much tut-tutting in the financial press that the hottest stocks were low-priced, "low quality" names, ones that had been beaten up in prior years. We've come full circle.   The similar incidence of $100 stocks today and in 1997 creates another point of resonance between the present environment and the one of a decade ago -- an analogy cited here more than once before.   The '97 market was, like today's, animated by a favorable supply/demand backdrop for stocks, the broad assumption that globalization offers vast opportunity and little risk, and hot money flushing into emerging markets. The '97 stock market wobbled early in the year, then levitated to repeated new highs into late summer.   Of course, it was accompanied by collapsing long-term interest rates and a strengthening dollar, both absent this year. And even still, a flutter in the Asian markets dropped the S&P by 11% in 20 days in October 1997 -- thus knocking a number of cloud-skirting stocks back to the double-digits.   The idea aired here in January that health-care stocks are finally set to perform well is panning out, with large-cap health stocks up 8% in '07, versus the market's 6%.   Morgan Stanley's Henry McVey is sticking with his bullish stance on health care, based on prospects for forecast-beating results in the second half. He favors Merck (MRK), Abbot Labs (ABT) and St. Jude Medical (STJ), among others.   One hazard is that the Street has become quite bullish on the sector. Given that, perhaps it's best to avoid the most-loved health stocks with fundamental challenges and punk stock-price action; Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and Amgen (AMGN) fit that description.   ---   E-mail: michael.santoli@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Saudi Aramco and Dow Announce the Signing of the Memorandum of Understanding to Develop One of the Largest Grassroots Plastics and Chemicals Production Complexes in the World
Story: The project will facilitate the development of downstream conversion industries in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia       DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, May 12 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Saudi Aramco, a fully-integrated, global petroleum enterprise and the world's leading energy supplier, and The Dow Chemical Company, the world's leading science and technology company, providing innovative chemical, plastic and agricultural products and services to consumers around the globe, today announced the signing of a detailed Memorandum of Understanding regarding the construction, ownership and operation of a world-scale chemicals and plastics production complex in Saudi Arabia, named the Ras Tanura Integrated Project.  The parties will now enter the final negotiation phase for the formation of a joint venture company to build, own and operate the facility to be located near Ras Tanura in Saudi Arabia's Eastern Province.  The Ras Tanura petrochemical joint venture will be operationally integrated with Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura Refinery complex and its Ju'aymah gas processing plant, two of the largest facilities of their kind in the world. The latter two facilities will supply feedstock to the joint venture and continue to be owned and operated by Saudi Aramco.     The proposed JV partnership will bring together the world's largest oil company with the world's leading chemicals and plastics producer and marketer. The Ras Tanura integrated complex will produce an extensive and diversified slate of plastics and chemicals and introduce new value chains and performance products to the Kingdom.  When fully operational, the new complex will be one of the largest grassroots plastics and chemicals production facilities in the world and will be ideally positioned to serve major world markets.     "This project will leverage our largest refining asset and enhance its profitability by capitalizing on the value addition opportunities and synergies existing between refining and petrochemicals," said Saudi Aramco President & CEO Abdallah S. Jum'ah. "The wide range of chemical materials and plastics to be produced by the joint venture will help spawn other downstream chemical conversion industries, thus strengthening the role of the chemical sector as a key enabler of many other future investments in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia," Jum'ah added.  "The downstream industries to be fed by the materials to be manufactured by the joint venture will assist in further expanding the national economic base while promoting economic diversification and capitalizing on the vast job creation potential of these industries."     "We are extremely pleased to be selected by Saudi Aramco as their joint venture partner to help build the Ras Tanura petrochemical complex.  This joint venture will further strengthen Dow's presence in the Middle East and add to our already vast capabilities worldwide," said Dow Chairman and CEO Andrew Liveris.  "Furthermore, the complex will have a long-term, secure and reliable feedstock position with integration to the adjacent refinery and gas processing plant, while positioning the new enterprise to grow its product sales."     The Ras Tanura petrochemical complex will produce a broad range of both basic and performance products, including ethylene, propylene, aromatic and chlorine derivatives.  Initially, the project scope includes world-scale production units for polyethylene, ethylene oxide and glycol, propylene oxide and glycol, chlor-alkali, vinyl chloride monomer, polyurethane components, epoxy resins, polycarbonate, amines and glycol ethers.        About Dow     Dow is a diversified chemical company that harnesses the power of innovation, science and technology to constantly improve what is essential to human progress. The Company offers a broad range of products and services to customers in more than 175 countries, helping them to provide everything from fresh water, food and pharmaceuticals to paints, packaging and personal care products. Built on a commitment to its principles of sustainability, Dow has annual sales of $49 billion and employs 43,000 people worldwide. References to "Dow" or the "Company" mean The Dow Chemical Company and its consolidated subsidiaries unless otherwise expressly noted. More information about Dow can be found at http://www.dow.com.        About Saudi Aramco     Saudi Aramco is a fully-integrated, global petroleum enterprise, and a world leader in oil and gas exploration and production, refining, distribution, shipping and marketing. The company manages proven reserves of over 260 billion barrels of oil, the largest of any company in the world, and manages the fourth-largest gas reserves in the world. Saudi Aramco operates one of the world's largest integrated gas gathering, processing and industrial distribution systems. These strengths, combined with the massive resource base of oil and gas, have allowed the company to fuel and feed the Kingdom's burgeoning petrochemical business over the past three decades. Saudi Aramco, which is also among the top ten refiners in the world, also owns and operates one of the world's largest tanker fleets to help transport its crude oil production, which amounted to over 3.2 billion barrels in 2006. In addition to its headquarters in Saudi Arabia's Eastern Province city of Dhahran, Saudi Aramco has affiliates, joint ventures and subsidiaries spanning the globe, with presence in the United States, Europe and Asia. More information about Saudi Aramco can be found at http://www.saudiaramco.com.    SOURCE  The Dow Chemical Company       /CONTACT: Jamal Kheiry, +966-3-874-5350, jamal.kheiry@aramco.com, or Neville Roome, +966-3-874-5419, neville.roome@aramco.com, both of Saudi Aramco; Chris Huntley +1-989-859-5588, chuntley@dow.com, or Louis Vega +971-50-457-9649, LAVega@dow.com, both of The Dow Chemical Company; or Joanna Steele, jsteele@golinharris.com, or Upasna Swain, uswain@golinharris.com, both of GolinHarris for The Dow Chemical Company, +971-4-332-3308, fax: +971-4-331-6733,      /Web site: http://www.dow.com      /Web site: http://www.saudiaramco.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 06:00 ET (10:00 GMT)

Headline: CBS Radio Drops Pair Of New York Shock Jocks Over Asian Slurs
Story: NEW YORK (AP)--One month after the firing of radio host Don Imus for broadcasting sexist and racist gibes, a pair of suspended New York shock jocks have been permanently pulled from the air by CBS Radio for a prank phone call rife with offensive Asian stereotypes.   "The Dog House with JV and Elvis," hosted by Jeff Vandergrift and Dan Lay, "will no longer be broadcast," CBS Radio spokeswoman Karen Mateo said Saturday. CBS Radio, a unit of CBS Corp. (CBS),  dismissed broadcasting hall of famer Imus in April for his defamation of the Rutgers women's basketball team.   The cancellation of the show, nearly three weeks after the show hosts were suspended, was another indication of the increased scrutiny on radio hosts and the heightened management sensitivity to complaints in the wake of the Imus firing.   "This is a victory not only for the Asian-American community, but for all communities who find themselves constant targets of racist and sexist programming," said Jeanette Wang, an executive with the Organization of Chinese Americans.   Mateo declined any further comment on the "JV and Elvis" show, which had aired on WFNY-FM immediately after the shock jock pairing of Opie and Anthony.   Gregg "Opie" Hughes and Anthony Cumia return to the station's airwaves Monday after issuing their own apology for a segment on their satellite radio program where they laughed as a homeless man fantasized about raping Condoleezza Rice and Laura Bush.   Vandergrift and Lay made their comments one day after Imus' April 4 meltdown on his nationally syndicated program. The pair broadcast a call to a Chinese restaurant; the caller, in an exaggerated accent, placed an order for "shrimp flied lice," claimed he was a student of kung fu, and compared menu items to employees' body parts.   The initial airing of the call went unnoticed, but a re-airing of the segment after Imus's firing prompted an outcry from Asian-American groups. Vandergrift and Lay were initially suspended without pay, but Asian-Americans quickly demanded the same penalty applied to the much higher-profile Imus.   Mateo wouldn't comment on the status of the DJs' contracts or whether they were still on the CBS payroll. Imus plans a $120 million breach of contract suit against CBS Radio.   As word spread about the fate of JV and Elvis, more than 100 people turned out for a Union Square rally to offer support for those two, Imus and other radio personalities under fire.   "It's not about whether you like what you heard or not," said Debbie Wolf, president of People Against Censorship. "I find censorship to be far more offensive than anything that was said."   The Rev. Al Sharpton, who played a major role in Imus' ouster, said Saturday that he wanted to meet with Hughes and Cumia's bosses at XM Satellite Radio Holdings Inc. (XMSR) over the rape comments on their show.   "My personal feeling is they should have already been fired," said Sharpton, who one night earlier had debated Imus producer Bernard McGuirk on the Fox News Channel. McGuirk was also fired from WFAN-AM.   McGuirk called Sharpton a "race-baiter" looking for attention when he led the campaign to fire Imus. Sharpton replied that Imus and McGuirk got what they deserved for making racist, sexist comments on the air.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 15:05 ET (19:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Blue Nile   -- NILE-NNM     Hold   -- Price 47.35 on May 8   by McAdams Wright Ragen     [Jewelry retailer] Blue Nile reported 1Q07 earnings of 19 cents per share, handily beating consensus of 15 cents per share and prior-year earnings of 13 cents, and the top end of management's guidance range. . . . Revenues increased 34% year-over-year to $67.9 million. . . . Particularly strong were sales of high-end diamonds. Based, in part, on management's updated guidance, we've revised our2007 estimate . . . [to] 92 cents per share, versus prior 86-cent estimate. . . . Despite strength, stock appears fully valued . . . it trades at 51.5 times our revised '07 earnings estimate. Raising target to 45 from 34, or 49 times our '07E; reiterate Hold.     Cosi   -- COSI-NNM     Buy   -- Price 4.80 on May 8   by Wedbush Morgan     Maintain Buy and 7 target. We continue to believe Cosi [owner, operator and franchiser of 130 cafe units; firm's market-cap, $192 million] has potential to grow units and revenue in excess of 20%, compared to our estimate of 8% industry revenue growth. Our target continues to be based on a 20% discount to the 1.7 times enterprise value/'07 estimated revenue multiple of Cosi's quick-casual peers, reflecting Cosi's relative size and liquidity.     Cutera   -- CUTR-NNM     Buy   -- Price 29.24 on May 8   by Lazard Capital Markets     Cutera laser and light-based systems . . . [are used by] dermatologists, surgeons . . . and others practitioners. Cutera preannounced 13% revenue shortfall, but doubt remained about whether problems were affecting Cutera specifically or whole cosmetic-laser industry, [or if they were] nonrecurring. . . . We [don't] expect shortfall to carry through rest of '07. . . . Our new 29 target (prior: 39) is, net of $7 cash, 17.6 times our one-year forward (2Q08-1Q09) earnings-per-share forecast of $1.25, at 1.1 PEG [price-to-earnings-growth], below med-tech mean.     Entercom Communications   -- ETM-NYSE     Market Perform   -- Price 27.18 on May 8   by Barrington Research     Radio broadcaster ETM [100+ stations in 23 U.S. markets] reported EPS of a 1-cent loss, close to our estimate of 0 cents . . . it included a one-time tax charge, which our estimate reflected. The EPS would have been 9 cents on adjusted basis. . . . M&A activity has been significant, potentially strengthening results in the future but complicating comparisons in current time frame and adding to expense levels . . . there will be an increase in Red Sox sports rights amortized over the months of baseball season. Favorably, a newly acquired station is being used to simulcast these games and extend other sports programming to a broader market.     Global Sources   -- GSOL-NNM     Buy   -- Price 18.80 on May 8   by W.R. Hambrecht     Target: 22. GSOL is one of the largest B2B commerce companies in China. . . . We believe GSOL is well positioned for . . . positive trends including international-trade growth, adoption of online marketing . . . and [a] strategy to cross-sell services across multiple media platforms. However, a tough industry environment . . . and other emerging companies are key risks. . . . Our target implies 19 times our '08 EPS estimate plus cash.     Hewlett-Packard   -- HPQ-NYSE     Sell - Price 43.80 on May 8   by Think Equity     HPQ preannounced slightly better-than-expected earnings and guidance for the quarter. . . . Personal PC systems were the driver. Note: HPQ only squeezed 1 cent more EPS from $1.4 billion more in revenues -- less than 40% of its current net margin. Raising target to 35, but reiterate Sell rating on slowing incremental margins.   HPQ prereleased earnings for April quarter . . . a week early because an internal e-mail with this information was accidentally sent outside the company.     Pfizer   -- PFE-NYSE     Market Perform   -- Price 27.38 on May 8   by First Global Securities     Pfizer managed to report a decent top-line growth of 6% year-over-year in Q1 [of calendar] '07, unlike in the past, where top-line growth was almost flat and much of the EPS upside was achieved on . . . cost-controls . . . EPS [was] 68 cents, 11 cents ahead of our and consensus estimates. However . . .  management deci[ded] to lower full-year EPS guidance range by 10 cents, despite strong quarterly performance, to incorporate earlier-than-expected entry of Norvasc generics and maintain earlier revenue guidance range of $47 billion to $48 billion.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Suzlon Windenergie GmbH: Notification to the Shareholders of REpower Systems AG pursuant to sec. 23 para. 1 sentence 1 no. 2 of the German Securities Acquisition and Takeover Act (Wertpapiererwerbs- und Ubernahmegesetz - "WpUG")
Story: COLOGNE, Germany--(BUSINESS WIRE)--May 12, 2007--   On 28 February 2007, Suzlon Windenergie GmbH (GER:RPW), Cologne, Germany, published the offer document for its voluntary public takeover offer to all shareholders of REpower Systems AG, Hamburg, Germany, to acquire all non-par value bearer shares (ISIN DE0006177033) in REpower Systems AG ("REpower Shares" and individually "REpower Share") against payment of a cash consideration amounting to EUR 126.00 per REpower Share. On 5 April 2007, the consideration offered has been increased to EUR 150.00 per REpower Share. The offer has been made available on the internet at the website http://www.suzlonwindenergie.com. The acceptance period for this takeover offer, which should originally expire on 20 April 2007, has been extended by two weeks and thus expired on 4 May 2007, 24:00h (Central European Time).     On 12 April 2007, the registered share capital of REpower Systems AG has been increased to EUR 8,928,176.00. Accordingly, the total number of voting rights in REpower Systems AG henceforth amounts to 8,928,176.                                      I.     The Federal Cartel Office (Bundeskartellamt) approved the completion of the acquisition of REpower Shares by Suzlon Windenergie GmbH on 5 March 2007 without imposing any obligations (Auflagen) or conditions (Bedingungen). The circumstances described in section 4.2.2 of the offer document did not occur. Thus, the conditions precedent of the takeover offer by Suzlon Windenergie GmbH set in section 4.2 of the offer document are fulfilled. The takeover offer will be implemented.                                      II.     During the acceptance period, the takeover offer, which has now been implemented, has been accepted for in total 7,427 REpower Shares. This corresponds to about 0.08 % of the share capital and the voting rights in REpower Systems AG.     Thus, Suzlon Windenergie GmbH holds today 7,427 REpower Shares, corresponding to 0.08 % of the share capital and the voting rights in REpower Systems AG     SE Drive Technik GmbH, Bochum, Germany, a person acting in concert with Suzlon Windenergie GmbH, holds today 692,480 REpower Shares, corresponding to 7.76 % of the share capital and the voting rights in REpower Systems AG.     Martifer Energy Systems SGPS, S.A., Oliveira de Frades, Portugal, a person acting in concert with Suzlon Windenergie GmbH and a subsidiary of Martifer SGPS, S.A., Oliveira de Frades, Portugal, holds 1,541,118 REpower Shares today, corresponding to 17.26 % of the share capital and the voting rights in REpower Systems AG.     Martifer SGPS, S.A., a person acting in concert with Suzlon Windenergie GmbH, holds 519,670 REpower Shares today, corresponding to 5.82 % of the share capital and the voting rights in REpower Systems AG.     These 2,760,695 voting rights aforementioned are attributed to Suzlon Windenergie GmbH and the persons listed below pursuant to sec. 30 para. 1 sentence 1 no. 1 WpUG and sec. 30 para. 2 WpUG respectively (see section 5.9 of the offer document), which are acting in concert with Suzlon Windenergie GmbH, provided that the REpower Shares are not already held by the relevant person.     Thus, 2,760,695 voting rights in REpower Systems AG, corresponding to 30.92 % of the share capital and the voting rights in REpower Systems AG are held or attributed to the following persons: Suzlon Windenergie GmbH, SE Drive Technik GmbH, AE-Rotor Holding B.V., Hengelo Ov, The Netherlands, Suzlon Wind Energy Limited, London, United Kingdom, Suzlon Energy Limited, Port Louis, Mauritius, Suzlon Energy Ltd., Ahmedabad, India, each member of the SUZLON Shareholder Group (as defined in section 5.4.4 of the offer document and as listed in annex 5.8, section 2 of the offer document), Martifer Energy Systems SGPS, S.A., Martifer SGPS, S.A., MTO SGPS, S.A., Oliveira de Frades, Portugal, Carlos Martins, Ilhavo, Portugal, Dr. Jorge Martins, Viseu, Portugal, Mota-Engil SGPS, S.A., Oporto, Portugal, Mota GESTAO E PARTICIPACOES, SGPS, S.A., Oporto, Portugal, F.M. - SOCIEDADE DE CONTROLO, SGPS, S.A., Oporto, Portugal, and each member of the MOTA Shareholder Group (as defined in section 5.7.2 of the offer document and as listed in annex 5.8, section 5.1 of the offer document).     The total number of REpower Shares for which the takeover offer was accepted and the number of REpower Shares held by or attributed to Suzlon Windenergie GmbH or any person acting in concert with it totals today 2,760,695 shares (whereas each voting right was counted only once). This corresponds to 30.92 % of the share capital and the voting rights in REpower Systems AG.                                     III.     Shareholders of REpower Systems AG who have not yet accepted the offer may still do so within a period of two weeks after this announcement. Headline: Barron's(5/14) The Electronic Investor: Giving Bonds An Electronic Upgrade
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Theresa W. Carey   To enable its listed companies to offer up more of their balance sheets to efficient trading and to enhance fixed-income market liquidity generally, the New York Stock Exchange is relaunching its bond platform this quarter. The upgraded electronic bourse should end at least some of the fragmentation in corporate bond trading, an enormous marketplace that's still mostly off-exchange -- which means retail investors typically buy from and sell to a brokerage's internal inventory.   Finding out whether you're getting the best available price for a stock trade is easy these days, thanks to the wide availability of real-time quotes. If you want to get the latest quote for, say, General Electric (ticker: GE), you just type the ticker into a quote box. Bond-price quotes, particularly for the many thinly traded names, are considerably more difficult to locate than stocks'. The market's complexity is partly to blame. There is one class of GE stock available in the U.S., but many, many more GE bond issues, all at varying interest rates and maturity dates.   During June, the NYSE will launch a bond-information site at http://www.nyse.com/bonds that will provide 20-minute delayed bond-price quotes as well as a look at the market for individual bonds. The site will contain listings of all available bonds and give users the ability to search the inventory, based on criteria such as maturity date, coupon, and industry sector.   What will this mean to individual investors? The NYSE's goal, according to John Holman, vice president and head of fixed income for the exchange, is to open up the bond market, increasing the visibility of pricing and adding liquidity. Holman says that the NYSE is making it simpler for liquidity providers, such as brokerage houses, to link into the platform.   "Having centralized information always drives the cost of execution down, which is an advantage to the retail investor," adds Holman.   The new platform started with 1,000 bonds and is adding about 500 new issues every few days with the eventual goal of 5,000 to 6,000. Government bonds will eventually be available.   Currently, brokers that allow their customers to trade using Townsend Analytic's RealTick platform, including Terra Nova Trading and MasterTrader, can view data and place trades on the NYSE bond platform. Holman says several online brokers, including Fidelity, are currently working on giving their customers access. "We hope the online discount brokers hook up to us," says Holman.     Why We Prefer Barron's     Consumer Reports magazine's newly released ranking of online brokerages is strikingly different than the one Barron's compiled back in March. CR's top-ranked firm, Firstrade, for instance, came in tenth in our comparable category and its runner-up, E*Trade, was sixth in Barron's.   Some readers have inquired about the differences. Actually, the results aren't so shocking in light of the criteria the two publications use. We're definitely biased, but we happen to like ours better.   The differences mostly stem from the target audiences. Barron's seeks to address a more sophisticated investor with a more comprehensive array of broker tests. Our online-brokerage client profile is a relatively wealthy individual with at least $100,000 in his or her account who is a moderately active trader and technologically savvy. Consumer Reports' Money Lab's target reader is a "typical small" investor who, the service says, "makes two or three stock trades a month at most" and "adds steadily to . . . core mutual-fund holdings."   CR rates only Web-based systems (Barron's also assesses software-based brokers) on trading cost and scope, minimum trade fees, mutual-fund programs, the number of mutual funds available without a transaction fee, banking and asset-management services, the amount of free research and education tools, and customer support.   Barron's evaluates the trade experience, technology, usability, product selection (with partial credit for items available only via a live broker), research amenities, portfolio analysis and reporting (with an emphasis on tax reporting), the quality of help and means of access, and costs of the Website or software program.   For Barron's, high-quality trade execution, smart-order routing technology (which finds the best bid or offer), and the absence of internalized orders and reliance on payment for order flow were necessary to earn a high rating. CR's rankings don't consider any of these criteria.   Another key difference: Our emphasis is on hands-on testing. We get a trading account with each broker, and run the sites and software offerings through a comprehensive script. I'll leave it at that.   ---   e-mail: electronicinvestor@yahoo.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
