Headline: Teijin, Sumitomo Corp Tie Up In Recycling PET Bottles -Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--Teijin Ltd. (3401.TO) will join forces with Sumitomo Corp. (8053.TO) to develop an efficient system for recycling discarded PET bottles collected by local governments.  The polyester maker will by the end of this month begin reprocessing used bottles into PET resin at a group firm's factory, The Nikkei reported in its Sunday edition.   In cooperation with the Japanese subsidiary of Norwegian recycling solutions provider Tomra (TOM.OS), Sumitomo has signed a deal with the Adachi Ward government in Tokyo to install 17 "reverse vending machines" in commercial facilities and other locations inside the ward for the purpose of chopping up collected used PET bottles.  Sumitomo Corp. aims to install 2,000 such machines nationwide by 2009.   Teijin Fibers Ltd., a Teijin group company, will purchase chopped-up PET bottles and reprocess them into PET resin at its factory in Yamaguchi Prefecture.  It will sell the resin to soft drink bottle makers.   The partners aim to recover 130 tons of used PET bottles, a volume equivalent to 4.33 million 500ml PET containers.   Recycling used PET bottles helps curb oil consumption, but no integrated system from collecting used bottles to reprocess them into PET resin currently exists in Japan.   Chinese companies have recently been buying used PET bottles at high prices to meet rising demand there.  For this reason, an increasing number of exporters are buying the PET bottles from local governments.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 08:06 ET (12:06 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(5/14) European Trader: The Sarkozy Revolution
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Matthew Curtin and Arindam Nag   France spoke with force when it chose a president for the 21st century. It's not just the margin of conservative candidate Nicolas Sarkozy's victory -- an estimated 53% to Socialist Segolene Royal's 47% -- that makes the result so noteworthy. It's the record turnout in both rounds of the election. There seems to be strong popular support for Sarkozy's determination to make the French accept more personal responsibility for the future and rely less on the state.   Thisis a big departure. The forces of globalization flooding the planet -- from international adoption of market-oriented economic policies, trade liberalization, immigration, and new technology to subdued inflation -- haven't been lived well by France's politicians.   Most -- including outgoing President Jacques Chirac, who was nominally of the right -- have sought refuge in a sort of market-Leninism. It's characterized by a grudging acceptance of the market and a bewildering confidence in the French state to micro-manage the economy from bureaucrats' offices in Paris, best seen in the 35-hour-work-week law.   So it will be a small revolution if Sarkozy can implement his program of lowering taxes, a simplifying France's labor code, conditioning unemployment benefits on active job hunting, granting greater autonomy for schools and universities, and applying another dose of pension reform.   By attacking structural economic weaknesses like these, a Sarkozy government might allow the economy to grow closer to its potential, creating more jobs, and, coupled with modest streamlining of the public sector, reduce government debt and balance the budget after two decades of deficits.   Nonetheless, cynical interpretations of the result are inevitable.   First, the power that France has already devolved to Brussels and the constraints of its stretched budget give Sarkozy little room for maneuver.   Secondly, Sarkozy's no radical. His confidence in market-based solutions didn't preclude backing a government bailout of Alstom and much campaign talk about asserting political control over the European Central Bank.   And parallels with certain other countries -- many observers would like to think of Sarkozy as France's Margaret Thatcher or Ronald Reagan -- are inappropriate because France is different, and resistent to change.   But if not a Reagan or a Thatcher -- and France's troubles arguably are less worrying that those faced by the U.S. and the U.K. in the late 1970s -- Sarkozy may yet have the impact of Gerhard Schroeder in Germany or the early years of the Tony Blair government in Britain in triggering a French renaissance.   And as Sarkozy prepares to fight to get a parliamentary majority to back his presidency, the irony that Blair and Schroeder were leaders of left-wing parties surely can't be lost on France's antediluvian Socialist Party.   If a report on German radio is true, France's biggest state-controlled enterprise, EdF (ticker: EDF.FRANCE), hasn't wasted much time after the election of the country's new president to approach Berlin about a plan to tie up with German rival RWE (RWE.GERMANY).   Leaving aside the compelling industrial and political logic behind the creation of a Gazprom-rivaling, 159 billion euros European energy behemoth, but not forgetting the antitrust obstacles, this is a deal that won't get done unless Berlin and Paris see eye to eye on European energy policy.   So an EdF-RWE partnership might yet be some way off.   But the carefully worded denials from the two companies are unlikely to puncture speculation that something is afoot. The circumstantial evidence pointing toward a merger of this scale and at this juncture looks compelling. Politically vetted cross-border industrial mergers in Europe's energy sector is in vogue.   Look at Enel's (ENEL.ITALY) successful tilt at Endesa (ELE.SPAIN) with the overt backing of the governments in Rome and Madrid, which stymied E.On's (EDA.GERMANY) takeover bid for the Spanish utility.   French President Sarkozy was slated to meet German counterpart Angela Merkel over the weekend. It would hardly be a surprise if energy policy was high on their agenda. After all, it's the financial and technological challenge of meeting the EU's future energy needs while protecting the environment that ultimately is driving consolidation in the sector. That and the EU Commission's determination to promote competition to keep prices low.   As for Sarkozy, the prospect of taking on the two biggest taboos for the ferociously left-wing trade unions in France's energy sector -- full privatization of EdF and ending their workers' preferential pension benefits -- no doubt appeals. Sarkozy has said he's open to the idea of the state reducing its stake in EdF, which a share offer for RWE would entail.   Increasing the number of years that employees at state-controlled enterprises like EdF have to work to qualify for retirement benefits, bringing them in line with the rest of the country, is one of Sarkozy's top reform pledges.   Finally, it seems clear that with Sarkozy in the Elysee Palace, France is headed for a period of more muscular policy toward industry, which may go beyond the protection of so-called national champions that in recent years has been the focus of government attention.   Given its market capitalization and ability to generate free cash flow, mining and metals giant Rio Tinto (RIO.UK) shouldn't be the subject of takeover speculation. Yet the Anglo-Australian-listed copper and iron company had to deny speculation about a bid from BHP Billiton (BHP.AUSTRALIA) after its shares jumped over 10% last Wednesday.   True, a BHP-Rio Tinto deal makes sense industrially because it would diversify BHP's asset base and geographic presence. And BHP would be picking up Rio Tinto's stock on the cheap; it has been trading at a forward price-earnings multiple of less than 10, its lowest levels in 10 years. That's a 33% discount to Anglo American (AAL.UK) and 8% to BHP's Australian-listed shares.   The reason behind the discount isn't hard to find. Rio Tinto has proved conservative on making acquisitions, creating the impression it's missing out on growth opportunities. But the company has a relatively easy way to fix investors' poor perceptions of its prospects.   Management should take a closer look at various partnership projects and buy out minority shareholders. Rio Tinto owns 53% in Robe River Mines; Mitsui owns the rest. The present value of Rio's share in Bunet is estimated at $3.7 billion. It has majority ownership in coal assets with a combined net present value of nearly $3 billion. The combined value of all assets also owned by minority investors is well over $10 billion.   Buying them out would let Rio Tinto book all their operating income, some of which is growing faster than rest of the company's. It would improve the quality of Rio Tinto's earnings and offer the prospect of fatter dividends and bigger buybacks for investors. And management would show it does have an alternative to to sitting on its hands.   ---   MATTHEW CURTIN and ARINDAM NAG are contributors to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which the European Trader is based   ---                     DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES     Region/   Country    DJ Global          DJ Global          DJ Global     Point     Indexes,           Indexes,           Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg. Headline: Barron's(5/14) Barron's 500
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Vito J. Racanelli   The ascendance of capitalism across the globe has rewritten the rules in nearly every industry and spurred explosive growth in international trade. The biggest beneficiaries of these twin trends, from New York to London to Mumbai and Beijing, are allocators of capital and commodities, and the companies that supply them. Small wonder, then, that investment banks, asset managers and producers of oil, metals and steel scored best in the latest Barron's 500 survey, a unique ranking of U.S. and Canadian companies based on cash-flow returns on investment. This year top honors go to investment-banking powerhouse Goldman Sachs (ticker: GS), last year's runner-up, which nabbed a perfect grade of 4.0, nosing out No. 2-ranked Franklin Resources (BEN). The mutual-fund firm also earned a 4.0 but received a lower grade in one of the key measures by which the companies are ranked. The bronze went to Apple (AAPL), while Terex (TEX), a maker of cranes and giant trucks, took fourth place, and Paccar (PCAR), another truck maker, fifth. The Holt division of Credit Suisse crunches the numbers for Barron's, comparing companies on the basis of one- and three-year cash-flow returns, sales growth and stock-price performance. Our ranking illuminates which companies consistently generate strong and growing sales and cash flow -- the very things that lead, over time, to higher earnings and rising stock prices. The shares of all our top five winners are near 52-week highs.   The Barron's 500 rankings do not reflect the views of Credit Suisse analysts.   While this year's leaders owe their gains to a booming global economy, there are notable differences, too. Their price-earnings ratios, for one, range from a low of 11 for Goldman to a high of 30 for Apple, whose iPod franchise transformed the computer maker into a fast-growing company with a rich stock.   Last year's winner, Lehman Brothers (LEH), slid to 25th place this year, done in by a flat stock price. Noteworthy improvements, in contrast, were made by Aetna (AET), Microsoft (MSFT) and Health Net (HNT), all of which rose sharply in the latest ranking.   As for losers, an eclectic mix of construction, tech and auto companies came up short this year. BlueLinx Holdings (BXC), an Atlanta-based building-materials supplier, was hurt by the downturn in housing and placed last at No. 500.  The company recently reported a first-quarter loss of a penny a share on a 30.5% drop in revenue, to $957.1 million, but said its end-user markets, though weak, appear "stable." In an e-mail, CEO Stephen Macadam said: "We believe we are managing our business well in this environment, appropriately removing costs while continuing to invest in and execute our long-term growth strategy."   Other noteworthy laggards include Computer Sciences (CSC), Eastman Kodak (EK), Ford Motor (F) and Pulte Homes (PHM), which fell to 480 from last year's 62. Don't ignore the losers, however; many have become turnaround plays and buyout targets. Previous cellar-dwellers such as Maxtor and Clear Channel Communications (CCU) received takeover offers.   No ranking can tell a company's whole story; it's best used as a jumping-off point for future research. The Barron's 500 aims to identify companies that make the most of their invested capital and perform best for investors. Here's a closer look at the 2007 winners.     Goldman Sachs Group   There is an undeniable mystique to this globe-girdling financial firm, found perennially atop investment-bank league tables. Mystique goes only so far, however. The secret to Goldman's success is a more prosaic combination of hard work, business acumen and teamwork, all integral to a corporate culture that knows big rewards don't come without taking calculated risks.   "People and culture is what drives everything," says Chief Financial Officer David Viniar. "We have no inventory. No factories."   That culture has survived market crises and management transitions, including former Chairman Henry Paulson's departure in 2006 to become Secretary of the Treasury. He was succeeded as chairman and CEO by Lloyd Blankfein.   With its three divisions -- investment banking, trading and principal investments, and asset management -- "Goldman Sachs is in the sweet spot in the growth of global capitalism," says Rick Wetmore, a portfolio manager at Turner Investment Partners, which owns Goldman stock. "And it is at the heart of the proliferation of private equity moving into public markets."   Goldman placed heavy emphasis on China early on, building important relationships with corporate and government leaders that are paying off now, Wetmore adds. Last year, Goldman bought just under 5% of the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (601398.CHINA), before the bank's initial public offering. ICBC has been racking up robust results -- 2006 profits rose 31% --and has been a nice contributor to Goldman's revenue, says Wetmore.   ICBC gives Goldman a big leg up in China, where it is the best positioned global investment bank. "We've been in China a long time, with the first significant investment way back in 1994," says Viniar.   The New York firm's legendary trading prowess is another cash-flow generator, notes James Huguet, president of Great Companies, a money manager that holds Goldman shares for clients. Goldman typically doesn't pull back the veil to reveal how its traders make their money, which probably adds to its mystique. There is a certain amount of faith on the part of investors in the firm's ability to trade, "but they have proven to be the best at it," Huguet says, citing Goldman's avoidance, most recently, of the subprime-mortgage mess.   "We think we are the employer of choice," says Viniar, who also notes that "Goldman has the willingness to stick with our investments."   China isn't the only example. Goldman made a long-term commitment to commodities trading in 1981, when it picked up J. Aron, a commodities broker and Blankfein's then-employer.   Though Goldman's stock has rallied more than 30% in the past year, to 226, it trades below the market multiple at 10.6 times fiscal 2007 consensus estimates of $21.43 a share. In the fiscal first quarter ended February, net revenue jumped 22% from the year-earlier period, while earnings per share rose 31%. Return on equity was 38%.   Goldman's discount owes in part to the company's market sensitivity, and the relative opacity of its trading division. But the P/E could expand to 13 if return on equity remains in the the high-20% to low-30% range, Wetmore says.   What could knock Goldman from its rarified perch? A sharp or prolonged downturn in the global economy could hurt the company's business. Similarly, a single nasty trading quarter could send investors fleeing its shares. Then again, a nasty selloff probably would serve to make Goldman more attractive.     Franklin Resources   Our runner-up by a nose has nothing to hide. Like Goldman, this giant asset manager is reaping the rewards of global growth and capitalizing on industry changes.   Merrill Lynch analyst Cynthia Mayer notes that the strength of equity and bond markets in the past four years has attracted funds to money managers like Franklin, raising assets under management and fund-manager fees. Moreover, the money-management business is characterized by relatively high operating margins of around 30%, she says.   San Mateo, Calif.-based Franklin has additional aces up its sleeve. Through its Templeton Funds subsidiary, it has significant exposure to overseas markets at a time when many investors are clamoring for foreign stocks. In April, assets under management in Franklin's global/international equity funds rose nearly 20% year to year, to about $262 billion, while total assets also increased by 20%, to $600 billion.   Franklin's income series funds have been attracting U.S. baby boomers who are nearing retirement and looking for income-generating products, notes Shannon Reid, manager of the Evergreen Strategic Growth Fund (ESGAX). In general, Franklin has a well-recognized franchise among financial planners and gets "a lot of shelf space" from distributors, Reid says. Evergreen owns Franklin shares.   According to Franklin CEO Greg Johnson, the company's investments around the world in the past three to five years, such as a sales and investment office in India catering to local customers, are starting to pay off. "Today our funds are sold in 100 countries," he says.   Forty percent of Franklin's recent gross sales are international, compared with 25% five years ago, and 30% of assets under management come from overseas clients, versus 16% previously.   Franklin's shares have risen about 40%, to 135, in the past 12 months and trade for about 20 times 2007 consensus earnings estimates of $6.91 a share for the fiscal year ending September. Last year, the company earned $5.44, up 31%. Reid has "trimmed a bit" of his holding but remains an investor for the longer term.     Apple   The near-ubiquitous iPod MP3 portable music player has redefined Apple -- and the way we listen to music. Sales could reach 50 million units this year, up from just one million in 2003, and drive further gains in cash flow and earnings for Cupertino, Calif.-based Apple.   Another plus, to shareholders like Kevin Landis, manager of the Firsthand Technology Leaders Fund (TLFQX), is that Apple is asset-light.   "It is a dominant consumer-electronics brand, without any manufacturing of its own," Landis says.   Not having cash invested in factories and machinery is "a wise use of capital," Landis adds. Instead, Apple focuses on the intellectual property behind its products.   For all the attention on the iPod franchise, the company's incremental growth rests with other products, such as the soon-to-be released iPhone and the Macintosh personal computer, which continued an impressive comeback in the second fiscal quarter, ended March. MAC sales of 1.5 million were up 36% from the same quarter in fiscal 2006.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Telefonica Denies Reports On Brazil Asset Tie-Up With TI >TEF
Story: MADRID (Dow Jones)--Spanish telecommunications giant Telefonica SA (TEF) denied on Saturday Italian media reports that it's planning to merge its Brazilian operations with those of Telecom Italia SpA (TI).   A company spokesman said the agreement that last month allowed Telefonica to purchase a minority stake in the Italian company calls for the independence of management and assets of both companies abroad.   A Spanish-Italian consortium including Telefonica, Intesa Sanpaolo SpA (ISP.MI), Assicurazioni Generali SpA (G.MI), Mediobanca SpA (MB.MI) and Sintonia acquired in late April an investment vehicle that holds a 16.3% stake in Telecom Italia and 23.6% of voting rights.   The acquisition of the stake in Telecom Italia sparked market speculation that Telefonica could be trying to get its hands on Telecom Italia's Brazilian mobile unit TIM Participacoes SA (TSU).   Telefonica, which has expanded aggressively in Latin America, has a 50-50 joint venture in Brazil's Vivo Participacoes SA (VIV) with Portugal Telecom SGPS S/A (PT).   Telefonica is the world's fourth-largest telecommunications company by market value.     -Company Web site: http://www.telefonica.es     -By Santiago Perez, Dow Jones Newswires, (34) 618 528 681, Santiago.perez@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 05:08 ET (09:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Tracing Steel's Fiery Ascent -2-
Story: Their guidance was pretty subdued for the next quarter. But when you sit down and map the universe and say, OK, they've got $7 billion in sales, so how big is the distribution market and how much can they acquire? The total distribution market in the U.S. for all types of metals is $130 billion. The top dozen players are less than 50% of that. It is still a very fragmented market, with lots of opportunities for growth for a company like Reliance. There has also been talk the last two years about mills and service centers [which process steel and then resell it in a revised form] getting together and integrating.     Q: What do you think of that?   A: I think there would be a lot of pluses. If you could align the two in some way, the industry would be a lot more efficient, more customer-friendly with less volatile pricing. However, to get from here to there might be difficult, because if a mill suddenly bought a service center, the other service-center customers would run away. While the long-run answer is a good one, getting there is difficult. Layer on that the situation with Ryerson [RYI], a competitor to Reliance, where the private-equity firm Harbert Management is stirring things up because Ryerson has not lived up to its potential for an awfully long time. The trade press also says Arcelor Mittal Steel [MT] is looking at Ryerson so there is an end game. If those two were to join up, it might make others consider a relationship. If you go back 25 years, most of the mills owned their distribution.     Q: How is Reliance valued compared with its peers?   A: It is at seven times Ebitda [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization], about average compared to the peer group. Both Nucor and Reliance are trading at a little over 10 times their '07 earnings estimates. Nucor is at two-thirds the market multiple with a demonstrated growth rate the last five years in the 20% range. It has no debt and pays out $1 billion a year to shareholders in dividends and buybacks, and yet the stock is at 10 1/2 times. We know that growth in steel-making assets is gone, there are none. The store is empty. What people don't understand is that the downstream growth at Nucor is sustainable at a reasonable price.   The market has to get a little smarter and understand what is unique about Nucor. And it is not only Nucor. Steel Dynamics has a lot of the same characteristics. It's cheaper on an enterprise value [market value plus net debt]-to-Ebitda basis but about the same on a multiple-of-earnings basis. It is also one of the lowest-cost producers.     Q: So you are focused on capital redeployment and growth?   A: Yes, steel companies that can grow: It's not a bizarre topic, it's a viable topic. There are growth stocks in this sector and they should get premium multiples for the growth. Maybe market multiples. But at 10 times, they are pretty far away from that.     Q: Other companies obviously recognize the value.   A: What is disturbing is the increasing amount of European interest.     Q: Why?   A: Because typically their return requirements are lower than ours, and it makes it a lot more difficult to compete if you are looking at the same assets. Having said that, there are still lots of strategic combinations that have not happened yet.   There are two primary global themes in M&A in the steel industry. One involves the BRICs, ex-China, or BRIs -- Brazil, Russia and India are very rich with raw materials and they traditionally have been focused on the upstream side of the business. But they now are looking for downstream processors of their raw materials. So some of these transactions, like Russia's Evraz [EVR.UK] buying Oregon Steel, India's Tata Steel [TATA.INDIA] buying Corus and CSN's [SID] unsuccessful attempt to buy Wheeling-Pittsburgh [WPSC], are about going downstream.   The other theme, which has been less prevalent but is going to get bigger, is about Europe and Japan looking for exposure to high-value-added markets. There is increasing pressure on the Japanese companies in particular to expand their participation in the U.S. I could see Japanese or European interest in a company like AK Steel [AKS]. What makes AK Steel unique is that they are the buyers of the semi-finished steel made in Russia, Brazil and India, and they have one of the best consumer-durable franchises in this country While it would be a great fit for U.S. Steel, AK Steel's valuation is relatively rich for them. AK Steel would be worth more to a Japanese or European company, which would pay more to get into the automotive market in the U.S.     Q: What about reports that Arcelor Mittal is interested?   A: The notion of a Mittal bid for AK Steel is not credible. Mittal already is the largest player in many of AK Steel's key markets, and there most probably would be anti-trust issues. Far more compelling, in our view, would be interest by ThyssenKrupp (TKA.GERMANY], CSN or any of the Japanese steelmakers that are increasingly looking to follow their automotive customers into the domestic market.     Q: Thanks, Michelle.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: East India Villagers Free Kidnapped S Korea Steel Co Officials
Story: KOLKATA (AP)--Two Indian officials working for a South Korean steel company who were held hostage in eastern India were released unharmed early Saturday, police said.   The officials, who work for the South Korean based-Posco (005490.SE), the word's third-largest steelmaker, were kidnapped Friday by villagers concerned that the company's plan to build a steel plant in the eastern state of Orissa would displace thousands of people.   "They were released hours after midnight," said Deputy Superintendent of Police S.K. Upadhaya.   "No harm has come to them, but they are being examined by doctors," Upadhaya told The Associated Press by telephone.   Three Posco officials had traveled to the village of Gobindapur to meet with farmers about acquiring land when they were kidnapped. One of the three officials, a woman, was released soon after being taken hostage, but the two others were kept for 10 hours.   Abhay Sahu, the president of an activist group dedicated to fighting the Posco project, had said the hostages would not be released until the company pledged not to develop the site, the Press Trust of India news agency reported. But they were released after the villagers received assurances from Posco that they would not enter their village, PTI quoted Sahu as saying.   Posco officials could not immediately be reached for comment.   Posco's steel plant - which would be the largest single foreign investment in India - was approved by the Indian government last year as a special economic zone, making it eligible for tax breaks and exempt from some government duties.   Posco has said it will invest about $10.8 billion to build the plant and develop the area.   Many residents are strongly opposed to the project because they say it would require the displacement of about 20,000 people.   Police said the Posco officials had been warned by residents not to enter their villages without permission, but the three did not heed the warning.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 02:00 ET (06:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(5/14) Follow-Up: Alcoa s Promising Deal
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   Call it a takeover bid with a certain je ne sais quoi.   Pittsburgh-based aluminum giant Alcoa (ticker: AA) last week launched a surprise $26.9 billion hostile offer for Canada's Alcan (AL), its rival from French-speaking Montreal, in a move that may be designed as much to ward off any unwanted offers for itself as to grow the company.   "It's a multi-level chess game," says John Buckingham, manager of the Al Frank Fund (ticker: VALUX).   Barron's has been a fanof Alcoa for some time ("Alcoa's Shiny Prospects," Aug. 8, 2005) and we remain so. The company is carrying out an effective turnaround and the stock is attractively priced, trading at just 12 times estimated earnings for the year ahead.   An Alcan deal would give the combined company a 30% share of the world's aluminum market and pave the way for some big cost savings.   While the stock, did little between our 2005 story and early this year, it jumped 10% in February on rumors Aloca itself may become a target. And it climbed 8% this week after the Alcan bid, to 38, near a 52-week high. Frank's Buckingham sees the stock headed to as high as 73 over the next three to five years.   One Alcoa shareholder, hedge fund Jana Partners wants the company to withdraw the bid and put itself on the auction block. Jana has cited Alcoa's "long history of failing to generate shareholder value through acquisitions." A sale, of course, could help the stock, too.   Barron's bullishness on Alcan already has paid off. The stock, at 80, is up 91% since we ran a favorable piece on it a few years ago ("Hot Metal," Dec. 22, 2003).   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Sanyo: To Focus On Quality Control, Environmental, Battery Ops
Story: TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Sanyo Electric Co. (6764.TO) said Saturday it will strengthen its product quality control and hinted its solar and battery operations will be a major focus this fiscal year.   Under a new management policy for the current fiscal period through March 2008, the Osaka-based electronics maker said it will establish a division to monitor customer satisfaction and product quality. Sanyo also said it will focus on "environmental- and energy-related solutions."   The company said President Seiichiro Sano presented the new policy to company managers and executives throughout Japan on Saturday afternoon. It marked Sano's first major presentation to his company since taking over from predecessor Toshimasa Iue in April.   A company spokesman said Sano would present a new mid-term "master plan" for the company toward the end of this year.   Sanyo forecasts it had a group net loss of Y50 billion in the fiscal year ended March. It is struggling to recover its finances under the watchful eye of a group investors led by Goldman Sachs Group Inc., who last year invested $2.6 billion to bail out the company.   The company faces questions about its product quality, with recalls of its laptop and mobile phone batteries over the past six months.   In addition, analysts say it must focus more on its mainline battery and promising solar panel operations to regain profitability. The company currently makes a wide assortment of products, from washing machines to mobile phones.   Earlier this week, General Electric Co.'s (GE) Japanese unit said it had succeeded in its bid to take over Sanyo Electric Credit Co. Sanyo is also looking to sell its semiconductor business, according to individuals familiar with the negotiations, and its struggling mobile phone and digital camera divisions are also possible candidates for sale.   Former President Iue, a grandson of the Sanyo's founder, was against selling off its units. He cited his inability to work with Sanyo's investors and the slow pace of the company's recovery under his leadership as the chief reasons for his resignation.   Sanyo will report its results for last fiscal year through March on May 28.       -By Jay Alabaster, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2929; jay.alabaster@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 05:31 ET (09:31 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Bahrain-Based Investcorp Buys Nine US Hotels For $450 Mln
Story: DUBAI (Dow Jones)--Bahrain-based asset management company Investcorp (INVCORP.BH) said Saturday it has acquired nine hotels in the United States for $450 million.   The hotels, acquired from the Marriott (MAR), InterContinental (IHG), Hilton (HLT) and Starwood (HOT) hotel groups, are located in Illinois, Oklahoma, Florida, Texas and Virginia, the company said in a statement. Eight of the hotels have been purchased and the purchase of the ninth hotel is scheduled to be completed in July.   Andrew Charlesworth, Investcorp's Bahrain-based real estate specialist, said: "The acquisition of these hotels was well timed as there is considerable current momentum in the U.S. hotel industry. These nine hotels have attractive locations within five state capitals and, as a result, have high occupancy rates of around 70%."   Over the past decade, Investcorp has acquired real estate with an initial capitalization of approximately $6.5 billion, the statement said.     -By Ayesha Daya, Dow Jones Newswires; +971 4 3644962; ayesha.daya@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 09:51 ET (13:51 GMT)

Headline: Japanese Companies Working To Get Emissions Rights -Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--A growing number of Japanese companies, including Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. (6752.TO), are seeking to obtain greenhouse gas emissions rights by improving energy efficiency at their Asian production bases, The Nikkei reported in its Sunday edition..   Matsushita Electric will soon start measuring energy use at its nearly 60 factories in China.  It will use the data in formulating plans to reduce energy consumption at these factories next fiscal year and beyond.  For example, it will replace compressors used in air conditioning systems, as well as boilers, with more energy-efficient ones.   The company will aim to obtain under the U.N.'s Clean Development Mechanism greenhouse gas emissions credits equivalent to the CO2 reduction volume achieved through its efforts in China.   In March, the U.N. approved energy-saving measures Matsushita proposed implementing at its 10 Malaysian factories as worthy of CDM recognition, and the company started implementing the steps in April, aiming to secure 8,100 tons worth of emissions credits annually over the next 10 years.   Denso Corp. (6902.TO) is also taking steps to have energy-saving measures planned for its Malaysian car air-conditioner and other factories recognized as CDM projects by the U.N.  It hopes to obtain 200 tons worth of emissions rights annually by improving a system involving compressed air.   Japanese companies have so far gained emissions credits in China and other Asian countries by, for example, helping local partners produce electric power using such natural energy sources as wind and solar power, as well as biomass.  The Japanese government has approved 161 such projects so far, helping reduce an equivalent of 77.76 million tons in CO2 emissions annually in these countries.   But such projects appear to have reached a limit in these countries, prompting Japanese firms to seek new ways to obtain emissions credits there.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 12:39 ET (16:39 GMT)

Headline: Switzerland Investigating Alleged Crimes In BAE Arms Deals
Story: BERN, Switzerland (AP)--Swiss authorities have begun a legal investigation into allegations of corruption surrounding arms deals by BAE Systems PLC (BAE.LN), an official said.   Jeannette Balmer, a spokeswoman for the Swiss federal prosecutor's office, told The Associated Press late Friday that a criminal investigation is under way into suspicions of money laundering involving the British aerospace company, but declined to give further details - including the identity of any parties apart from BAE - so as not to prejudice the probe.   She said the investigation was the result of a report prosecutors received from the Swiss money-laundering authority.   The U.K.'s Defense Ministry said it was not aware of the Swiss investigation and could not comment until they had further details.   The U.K. government in December called off an inquiry into a multibillion dollar arms deal between BAE Systems and Saudi Arabia, saying it was acting to protect national security and British jobs. Prime Minister Tony Blair told lawmakers that continuing the Serious Fraud Office investigation "would do enormous damage to our relationship with Saudi Arabia," which, he said, was strategically important.   The SFO had been investigating allegations that BAE ran a GBP60 million "slush fund" offering sweeteners to Saudi officials, reportedly via Swiss bank accounts, in return for lucrative contracts as part of the Al-Yamamah arms deal in the 1980s.   Al-Yamamah, meaning "the dove," was the name given to an agreement under which BAE supplied Tornado fighter jets and other military equipment to Saudi Arabia. The full extent of the deal, which Saudi Arabia paid for by supplying the U.K. government - BAE's largest shareholder - with oil, was never revealed. However, it was widely believed to be the U.K.'s largest-ever export agreement.   Blair's decision to call off the SFO probe earned a complaint from the U.S. government and a strong rebuke in January from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which questioned whether the move conformed to the group's commitment to combat corruption. Britain is a member of the Paris-based OECD.   An OECD working group on bribery - led by Swiss jurist Mark Pieth - said in March it would continue to examine closely Britain's anti-corruption efforts.   The following month Britain's Guardian newspaper reported that London was exerting pressure on the OECD to have Pieth removed from his post to prevent further criticism of the conduct of government ministers and BAE in the affair.   The SFO in June last year asked Switzerland for legal assistance in its probe of the Saudi deal. The request was put on hold after the British government called off the probe, but never formally withdrawn.   Balmer said separate requests from the SFO for legal assistance into possible BAE bribes to Tanzania, Romania, Chile and the Czech Republic were also still being considered. She said prosecutors had yet to decide whether to pass on bank documents relating to these cases to British authorities.   The Czech case has caused concern in Sweden because it relates to a deal - later canceled - to sell 14 Gripen fighter jets to the Czech Republic as part of a joint venture between BAE and Sweden's Saab.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 10:17 ET (14:17 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Bolivia's Morales Vows To Proceed With Energy Nationalization
Story: LA PAZ, Bolivia (AP)--Bolivian President Evo Morales vowed to move forward with his campaign to nationalize Bolivia's oil and gas industry while presiding Saturday over ceremonies marking the transfer of two Brazilian-owned oil refineries to state hands.   Bolivia this week agreed to buy back formerly state-owned refineries from Brazilian state energy company Petroleo Brasileiro SA (PBR), or Petrobras, for $112 million.   On Friday, the government announced it would negotiate the purchase of a majority share in the Bolivian operations of four more foreign companies, as dictated by Morales' nationalization decree last year.   "We have not yet finished the job," Morales told a flag-waving crowd at the Guillermo Elder Bell refinery near the eastern city of Santa Cruz. "There is still work to do."   Morales was expected to attend a similar ceremony later at the Gualberto Villaroel refinery near Cochabamba.   The four businesses to be targeted are: pipeline company Transredes, part owned by Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA); the gas exploration company Chaco, owned by the British company BP (BP); gas exploration company Andina, subsidiary of the Spanish-Argentine company Repsol YPF (REP); and the Hydrocarbons Logistics Company of Bolivia, jointly owned by the German company Oiltanking GmbH and the Peruvian company Grana y Montero SA (GRAMONC1.VL).   Morales ordered the nationalization of Bolivia's oil and gas industry in a surprise decree on May 1, 2006. After six months of tense negotiations, the foreign companies were allowed to remain in the country but agreed to sell a controlling interest in their Bolivian operations to the state.   The foreign companies also agreed to pay higher taxes and royalties on their Bolivian earnings. South America's poorest country has since seen its petroleum revenues double to $1.3 billion in 2006 from $608 million in 2005, according to government figures.   But analysts worry that exerting too much state control could scare off the long-term foreign investment needed for the industry to grow.   On Saturday, Morales also reiterated his recent criticisms of the International Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes, or ICSID, a World Bank-sponsored arbitration court many companies turn to when fighting local government claims against their international investments.   Morales announced Bolivia's withdrawal from the ICSID last month, and foreign companies will only be able to present claims against Bolivia for the next six months.   Morales has said he believes the ICSID is biased toward transnational corporations, and has called for a global campaign to "eradicate" the court.   "Now is the time for us to mobilize and say 'no' those institutions that only allow the looting of the people, the looting of nations, and the looting of our natural resources," Morales said.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 16:29 ET (20:29 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: State Bank Of India 4Q Net Profit Surges 75% To INR14.93 Bln
Story: KOLKATA (Dow Jones)--State Bank of India (500112.BY) Saturday said its fiscal fourth-quarter net profit surged 75% on year to INR14.93 billion from INR8.53 billion a year earlier.   The state-run bank - India's largest, by asset base -said its total income for the January-March period rose 29% on year to INR144.36 billion from INR111.86 billion.   The bank reported a modest 3% rise in its net profit for the fiscal year ended March 31, to INR45.41 billion from INR44.07 billion a year earlier.   Its total income for the year also grew 4% to INR452.60 billion from INR434.15 billion.   The bank's board announced a dividend of INR14 per share for the last fiscal year.       -By Abhrajit Gangopadhyay; Dow Jones Newswires; 91 9831241778; abhrajit.gangopadhyay@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  May 12, 2007 05:27 ET (09:27 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
